I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs hard to understand about the fuzzy nature of the table as you begin enacting abrasive forces whether it‚Äôs cutting it or putting it through a sanding machine. If you pour honey on carpet and let it sit there it will be crispy, as you begin to work it even without soap or water it begins to fray itself from the brick it hardened in. It‚Äôs the same concept. Really not that difficult to understand that you are not changing the molecular level of denim you are just masking it and suppressing it. End of the day it is still jeans and still fuzzy just locked into a hardening agent.

Hi! Your question in  the Denim video as to why it feels kind of fuzzy when sanding or cutting is that you are essentially dealing with fabric which is made up of threads that are interwoven.  Whenever fabric is cut, depending on the fabric, each cut leaves a raw edge to the fabric threads. When you sand  the fabric, you are actaully "cutting" the fabric leaving many small edges. by using the expoy on top of the fuzzy threads, you are keeping the individual strands of thread grouped. In the old days, women would add wax to the end of thread when hand sewing to keep the indivial thread strands grouped together so that they could thread it through the eye of the needle. Hope that explaination helps. Great video!
Denim is cool.  I do wonder about mixing in different fabrics, carbon fiber, etc.  mostly for the color effects like you see in skateboards. Might get more psychedelic, which someone will like.
Omg that comment you screenshot! Oh well, I guess every comment is engagement.
I love the combination of "well I wouldn't want it in my home" and "but it's an awesome piece of ingenuity in design." I don't want to copy it, but this is the sort of content that leads to me being awake at 2am with an idea for something that I do want in my home one day, and I enjoy that a lot more than seeing something and just wishing I could copy that. Also, yeah, this is going to be strong. It's a fibre reinforced composite, like fibreglass but with cotton instead of glass fibre. If it doesn't have anything nasty happen to it, it's still going to be a solid tabletop in a thousand years' time.

Love the table, but here are a few ideas if you should ever try it again.  I am a quilter, so I work with cloth a lot.  After cutting the fabric, use a zigzag stitch or pinking shears on the edge.  Then wash the fabric, as it will remove the sizing, making the fabric a little softer, so you can squeeze the acrylic out of the material.  The acrylic will, of course, make it firmer again, but hopefully your shop floor will not be covered.  Then you can continue as you usually would.  I am sure you will find this much more enjoyable.  Still, I loved it, and I watched the whole thing with my puppy.

Denim Damascus. You can definitely get creative with the patterns. Replicating traditional Damascus patterns is fairly obvious. Probably using forms that taper from end to end, not just rounded edges, to get a little more control. But there‚Äôs so many more pattern options you could almost certainly do letters or simple logos. You can literally put anything under there that fits, like a section of chain link fence. But something that might be really cool is trying to replicate the classic denim wear patterns in the table.

Denim.  I really DO enjoy watching these Denim Tables.   I think it'd be cool if you made the base out of Denim as well. In fact, I think you should make more bases in general.   On a side note. You enjoy making bowties with your wood tables.   What if you got a really gnarly piece of wood, that would need a ton of bowties, just by looking at the slab. Then, instead of securing it with bowties, what if you bore out a big calligraphy design throughout the whole table, for the negatives.  You could get some 8 mil transparent plastic tarp, and with a sharpie parker, you could create a template for your positive shapes. Then, when making the positive shapes, you could get a different type of wood, a color that would contrast with the existing wood for the table. You'd basically cut out the shapes on your 8 mil plastic, and double sided tape it to your positive shapes.  Another side note, that "Think about it" guy. Did he teach you how to do woodworking?
Denim: What about spelling out something in the pattern, at least a little?   Apologies if already said in the 10K+ comments.  Love your channel, keep up the great commentary and risk taking. You won't believe this, but in 2014 I went to China with an MFG tour to find suppliers for my machine project.  I met the person who makes the BAC vacuum pot you are using. He really impressed me in the interview I had with him in Shanghai.  In China, there are 3 types of manufacturers; the first is the scammer, the second is the faker who has an empty factory and say they are moving and they will probably get you your product but it will be from another factory and they are just the middle men.  The third are the real ones, and Sam from Baco engineering is the real one.  His work for me keeps getting better and better. My youtube channel is just a hack around thing, so you won't find what I really do there, but I'm in inventor.

Pretty sure the reason you're getting "fuzzy" textures is the nature of the material and how a planer is radially cutting the material. A radial cutter will cut nicely in a small portion of the radius. It will also likely take "tearing" cuts in other parts, unless you can get perfect speeds/feeds, pulling the fabric up. This is all reliant on the planer taking a "conventional" cut. If it climb cuts it's a different story.

I may be late to the party, but here is why I think the table feels soft coming off the planer, even though the epoxy has completely penetrated the denim. I think because the epoxy is brittle compared to the denim fibre, the tool breaks the epoxy and then fails to cut the now loose fibre to the exact height of the epoxy surface. Essentially like casting a rope in resin and then breaking the end of it with a hammer just on a microscopic level. This is just a wild guess, but maybe you could use a really sharp hand plane (knife) and run it across to cut the short fibres sticking out. I hope this makes sense, excuse my bad English as I am  a native German speaker :)  EDIT: How about using a cheap disposable razor, I think those things are made to cut short stubble. YES, please shave the table!
Edit: there's a far better explanation already here in the comments   My best bet would be because the epoxy is Harding around the fiber not Harding the fiber it's self, a small layer of fibers from the denim become exposed and pushed flush because there's not brittle enough to snap off when cut just being pushed to the table while the plainer is running, witch in theory would give you that fuzziness especially if your losing microscopic amounts of epoxy dew to heat or friction. Just a theory tho

That type of correction (not the relative frustration or tone behind it) comes out of a desire for truth and and an interest in stopping the spread of false information.  With many things, false information is not harmful, but normalizing false (even incomplete) information as acceptable is how many misconceptions about vaccination and pharmaceuticals become so strong and broadly believed.   Please don't shame everyone who tries to share more accurate information where they perceive it to be lacking. Instead thank them for the correction, show them a change in the next video, and let them know if they came across too strong so that they can improve as well. A far better way than publicly declaring inconvenient truth to be undesired.  Very nice table by the way, I can see why you chose to experiment further with the coffee tables.

Denim is cotton, so when you sand it, even though it has been infused with epoxy, little hairs get pulled up and it creates a "nap."

I've never made a table out of denim micarta but I have made some knife and tool handles. It's great for it because of that fuzzy texture. It's really comfortable on the hand and I'm pretty sure the reason that it happens Is the epoxy has less tensile strength and abrasion resistance than the denim so the long flexible denim fibers stay inbeded in the epoxy and the hard epoxy breaks off. Come on just think about it

WOW, the look is amazing.  I have maybe an idea for your epoxy layups, you might try a metal fiberglass roller it has little tips, that force the epoxy in and thru the cloth and making sure that your epoxy is even and not leaving dry or air pockets. In the end you'll use less epoxy and have faster layup times. My only experience with glass and epoxy was repairing oil tanks, replacing bad metal sandblasting the metal, then laying up the   the repair area with glass and epoxy inside or outside the tanks and at times both. Thank you for sharing your art builds. üòä

Tiene mu buen aspecto. Para otra ocasi√≥n usa piezas cortadas en vez de enteras, con m√°s variedad de color (quiz√°s 4-5), de modo que al reducir luego el patr√≥n, no aparezca siempre el mismo color a la misma altura.
With jeans. I liked a more even layer, without bulges. But in any case, it is wonderful when you create and experiment. I advise you to rely more on your inner voice and your inspiration, because the irrational can give birth to a truly beautiful form or idea! The texture of this tabletop, in my opinion, is too contrasting. I dare to judge this as a designer by education and vocation. The rhythm of the spots is very similar across the entire surface of the table, for design it is better when there is a rhythm of the large and the small. You can learn from nature, for example, spy on the outlines of islands in the ocean from a bird's eye view, or any other natural textures. It would be interesting to add pieces of wood to the body of the tabletop along with jeans, and metal objects, thereby creating truly unique works of art. Thank you for your double work in products and in filming videos, this is very important for inspiring other people to create beautiful products!

For covering the floor , I prefer using roofing tar paper. By a couple rolls lay out on the floor and duct tape the seems. The epoxy can easily be scraped up or just through it away after several uses
For covering the floor , I prefer using roofing tar paper. By a couple rolls lay out on the floor and duct tape the seems. The epoxy can easily be scraped up or just through it away after several uses

The "Damascus" you see youtuber knife makers doing isn't real damascus.  What they are doing is "pattern welded steel".  Real Wootz or Damascus is a crucible steel that has those natural crystalline structures and patterns.  Here's a fascinating  history of Damascus Wootz. https://youtu.be/2MJHX5XPTJM?si=fVeTtAzn_GcZUj6S

"nobody likes you because you point out what real damsacus is!" Geeez, i thought he was gonna say thanks for pointing it what, but we know the difference between pattern welding and damascus steel..why bot just be nice and polite? sorry, that's so pretentious and even aggressive..   people point it out because it also has a very important historical context in steel production throughout history.. Damascus is a city first of all, and what people are referring to is Wootz steel..the first molten steel in crucibles and the first originated in india and some around middle east, Damascus was the city of great trade and the term was interchangeable of wootz steel and as is now damascus and particularly pattern welding technique. Pattern welding exist even before the roman age.  So there, hate me, nobody likes me, buhu, i like weapon history and metallurgy and not misconceptions..sue me  And most people DON'T know and are even ripped off by inauthentic products.

To avoid the fluffy effect you should try to leave the denim soaked overnight. Apply the epoxy with the roller, you only apply the epoxy superficially. For info: the "jean denim" is the name of the designer Jean and the city from which he immigrated from Nime, a French city :)

Denim
Hi, I'm interested in your opinion. I want to create tabletops using epoxy resin and gypsum. First, I'll print a mold on a 3D printer with patterns or solid figures around the entire diameter of the tabletop. Then, I'll pour gypsum into the mold to easily reproduce the same design in the future. After that, I plan to cast the gypsum in epoxy resin to produce the tabletops. Sorry if it's a bit difficult to explain in a non-native language. Thank you in advance!

Im far from being a denim epoxy table expert but I am a sewing expert and it might be down to the dressing used in fabric production that will resist any dyes or liquids like epoxy. The dressing is used to keep the fabric stiff and easy to handle, cut, roll etc. Washing it will remove it but also make it slightly harder to handle as it won‚Äôt keep its shape as much, it may also shrink or distort the fabric but not by a huge margin. Hope this helps!

This idea of the demascus denim is actually so cool but I keep looking at the contrast colors and thinking ‚Äúwhat if that glowed in the dark‚Äù and now I feel like it‚Äôs not a want but a needüòÇ
I‚Äôm not an epoxy expert but the reason it gets fuzzy after being cut is because it‚Äôs still fabric in the end. Sure it may be infused or coated in epoxy but it‚Äôs almost the same as putting a pizza in epoxy, cutting into it, and noticing it‚Äôs still kinda food textured. The only way I see that problem being resolved would be not sanding it to allow the top layer to stay in tact and glossy/glassy
Have you ever tried using an air compressor to pop the table out of the mold? The fuzziness is basically the fibers flexing and breaking the epoxy leaving that hazy look. Of course this is pure speculation but made sense in my mind as the fibers shift and the epoxy breaks but still attached leaving those microscopic infused "snowflakes" if you will. Putting a microscope to it would tell you better what is going on.

You said you don't like people who leaves comments like that but I thought it is important and you would probably appreciate hearing this from me.  Damascus is the name of the city where this method was created. However, Beside the method of steel fusion, also the steel itself is known as Damascus Steel which is a steel made of iron and carbon which made the Damascus steel unbreakable which the similar combination used by Japanese for crafting swards but Japanese didn't use multiple pieces of steel to create their swards as the Damascus Arabs did.  On the other hand, this city has been known with its textile too, it is called DAMASK.  I hope you will find these information helpful.

Denim Denim denim
Re your list:  It's officially OK to use _Escalator_ for the kind of thing in general, as (in a landmark case) they *lost* the trademark by not policing the usage enough.  It set the standard that companies follow today to keep their trademark distinct.   As for _Realtor_ , the Association of Realtors exist to make people think that members are superior and different to mere estate agents, so using it to mean estate agent in general is going to get them especially mad.  And if you do so in a published article, you _will_ get a letter from the lawyers explaining that it's their registered trademark.  Most of the items listed are _genericised trademarks_ , some of which are truly and legally genericised and some are still defended. Denim!
You are talented no doubt but this one is a strong no from me lol.  Love your content.

When Vaquforming plastic panels there are often a series of small vent holes drilled into the molds. Might be worth experimenting with to see if it helps or hinders the look you want.

I might have an answer for you on why it gets fuzzy again I‚Äôm no expert so don‚Äôt quote me on this, but I used to be a conveyor technician and we used a monofilament  belt that used to be coated with a type of urethane and because it‚Äôs a woven fabric once you break that coating whether it be liquid urethane or epoxy that holds it all together it cuts into those fabrics and it pops them up kind of like hook and loop. That would be my best guess and I can tell you that I used to have to buf the back of some of these conveyor belts to bond a tracking strip to it, and once that adhesive in the fuzzy was melted into the PVC tracking strip Created a bond like no other you couldn‚Äôt rip it off of there without destroying it again, just an opinion, and it might be the reason why it fuzzes up on you. I look at it like woven basket basically, and the weaves are coming apart once you sand them. I have to say this is one awesome build dude I really like it.
Denim. I enjoyed your video. üòä
Using a free form kidney shaped piece of 1/4 inch acrylic or abs could be used as a pusher into the corners around your wood blocks. Pushing it into the lower edges all around each block would give you a greater chance of eliminating any voids in the layers.  Another helpful point would be to put was fillets around your wood blocks making it easier to guarantee less voids in the corners.
If you could get a chance to buy a disc sander it would be safer for a majority of your sanding.  It won't do for your interior radii, but you'll probably have less blocks shooting on the floor üòä
Denim: and as one of the few Demascus denim experts in the world I‚Äôm glad you finally discovered vacuum resin infusion

Fuck you just ask questions and I am capable of creating so many ideas just from one thing. If you want to make a ... True denim build... Then you yourself must find it. you could lay down strips on top of strips to create intricate patterns when you shave down to a certain layer, you could take all sorts of denim strands and just toss and mix them up on the platform, you could lay different patterns, use different  years, look for that unique thing the only denim can do and only a certain way and you have your true demin what ever form it ends up as.
OH ... what happens when you plain Fiberglass. That's what this reminds me of. Fixing things on snowmobiles and boats, fiberglass. it has similar effect
because when you "enfused" the whole thing you compressed everything, so you basically end up with... how do I put this... Hard on outside, softer on inside, epoxy doesn't really soak into denim but you also have different threads as well. Denim was designed to handle wear and tear, to last. So their isprobably something already in the denim or it's just the nature of denim itself that creates a secondary effect that is only revealed in these situations.

I think the surface gets fuzzy again because denim is 100% fiber. Epoxy saturation doesn‚Äôt actually penetrate the individual fibers so they still have their original material characteristics when exposed. It‚Äôs like the fuzziness of fiberglass panels when sanded or cut.

You didn't infuse the job. What you do is lay everything down dry, apply the vacuum, and release the resin into the job. It's great seeing the resin flow through the laminate. Absolutely no air in the finished laminate.

My fuzzy thoughts‚Äîyour denim resists epoxy. 1.  Wash and dry first.  Most textiles are treated with a finish at the end of weaving.  The finish gives the fabric a stiffer feel, and is water resistant .  If it resists water, how much more so epoxy.  Don‚Äôt use anything like fragranced laundry detergent or fabric softener, which is another finish that resists water. 2.  Use a lighter weight denim.  Denim is a densely woven twill using highly twisted thread, manufactured to resist wear.  It comes in several weights, a lighter weight may be easier to saturate. 3.  Ask a scientist.  In my area, UCDavis has a fabulous textile science department.   They have grad students in their doctoral program who would enjoy hearing how you‚Äôre using denim and who will have lots of info on how to choose and prep the fabric.

As for the fuzziness, I think it is because the epoxy is coating and surrounding and getting between the fibers. It isn't making the fibers themselves hard. When you cut through the epoxy, you expose the still-soft fuzzy fibers underneath. PS: if you leave the table fuzzy, it will attract dirt like crazy and be hard to clean.

20:55 Call me stupid,  but my take is that denim is made with strands of tightly wound cotton, and under the microscope these look like twisted licorice, or a drill bit if you will. The epoxy will fill those helixes but the minuscule cotton hairs and strands will always be the skeleton imho. Love your stuff dude!

1) When you have small pieces like that, you can always stab a long barbecue fork vertically on the wood and twist it from far up over the router table ;D 2) Because the Epoxi gets on the outside of each string, but is too thick to go inside each string¬¥s core, denim cotton is a thick fabric too, tightly woven, the fuzziness comes from the cotton of those string¬¥s cores that the resin dindn¬¥t reach... same sort of thing happens, on a bigger scale, when you dye t-shirts at home, if you clump fabrics together tightly with elastic bands or something, the ink doesn¬¥t reach all the spots and some spots are left white... .

it gets fuzzy‚Ä¶ because there‚Äôs fabric in there lol.  but really though, my guess is because we‚Äôre thinking of it wrong: like the epoxy or resin or whatever it is, when saturated, is becoming fully ‚Äúone‚Äù with the coating. on the smallest scale though, it‚Äôs never truly combined. It‚Äôs not like adding something water soluble to water. It‚Äôs more like millions of tiny chocolate covered pretzels. no matter how well covered in chocolate it is you‚Äôre gonna get pretzel coming out when you bite.
denim I don't think you need to use plywood for the inlays. Try simply cutting shapes out of a foam camping mattress. vac bag it and see how much it compresses. It'd probably automatically give a soft transition w/o the need of rounding off the edges. Also, you might count how many layers you sanded through.  Unless the thick edge is important to you, you can probably get most of the damascus effect from fewer layers of denim, and less epoxy.

Denim.   This video has been rolling around in my head for a couple weeks.  I definitely see a psychedelic look in certain parts which I agree isn't my favorite.  But other sections remind me of natural wood grain that you might see in oak.   This got me thinking about trees and how grain naturally forms (or at least how I think it naturally forms).  Trees build layers circularly and continually add additional layers.  Then when the wood is milled, the cuts run across those layers that were built up, so with wood you get grain that naturally progresses through a large slab.   Contrast this with your process with denim where you built the layers horizontally and then processed it horizontally.  You get some flowing grain textures since you added the shaped pieces of wood but you're getting some undesirable aesthetics.  I think they look like lava lamp blobs.   I'm really interested in what further ideas you're hoping to explore.   I had two thoughts that I had to share to get off my mind.   First idea (reasonable), use a similar process with the pieces of wood but make them stretch the whole piece and minimize large flat sections.   I think this would create more natural "grain" progressions throughout the piece.   Second idea (less reasonable), build the piece by rolling demin and build the layers similar to how layers of a tree might develop. Then have it milled traditionally like a piece of wood. I have no idea what it would look like or how you would accomplish the rolling process with epoxy but I can't stop thinking about the concept.  Hope this gives you some amount of inspiration to continue your craft!
Denim ü´∂üèº

Why is it fuzzy? I mean, it's a bunch of long, loose fibres - when the planer or the sander violently rips thin layers off it, it's gonna rip up them tiny strings with a little bit of epoxy. Either that, or the epoxy you're using is too viscous to penetrate in-between the fibres, and only gets the whole strings that the denim is woven from. I'd guess both.

Denim... As to why it gets fuzzy. I'm imagining a paint brush that's hardened by shellac or poly. It'll get pliable again if you work it and break that infused shellac/poly off of it. The epoxy infused denim is probably doing the exact same thing as the tools cut across and work the fibers.

I‚Äôll be that guy as well‚Ä¶just to annoy you.  It‚Äôs pattern welded steel, never Damascus steel. The two are absolutely and fundamentally different steels in both the patterns and how they‚Äôre actually made. Traditional Nordic and Japanese steels are pattern welded.  Do you call paper cardboard or cardboard paper? No.  üòÇ  Have fun!

I would imagine that the reason you still feel fuzzy stuff when you sand is because the fabric is infused, but not every thread. Plus the thread is still in there. My hypothesis is that the texture is extra evident because the fabric is soft and the epoxy is hard. I saw a video explaining how your skin doesn't cut because the blade is using a back and forth motion. The skin being soft just moves with the saw instead of cutting. I suspect the fabric is doing the same.

To answer why it gets fuzzy when you sand and saw the finished piece, in my experience, even the most saturated and well infused home made micarta the fibers abrade out of the epoxy/ not be fully plasticized. As to making an unfinished denim epoxy table, the look and feeling is great, but given that it is still fabric, it will get dirty and stain quickly no matter what you do.

Denim. Appreciate your feedback as always. So here is some feedback, blunt and female. Forget the haters who think they know better than you, you are an artist, embrace this and let go of your need to impress anyone that is not you. You do not need approval from anyone because you are unique, talented and a free spirit. Your ability to create is a gift and anyone who does not see that is just plain jealous or a rigid ignoramus that thinks formal training makes them better than anyone else, this is simply not true because they are sheep with a one track mind where creatives are free to think for themselves and often produce better art. Mozart nor Monet where formally trained. Also as a seamstress who understands fabric I would suggest that the "fuzziness" is created because the denim has fibres just like wood grain or meat so the plaining is causing the fibres to break or frey causing the fuzzies. fabric has a bias so I would try laying the fabric on the bias and see if this does not produce a better result and it may also work better during the cryovac process to pull the fabric tighter to the wood. Bias is the cross grain so you will use a lot more fabric but you may get the results you are looking for. I would be very interested to know if you try this and it works. When the grain is at 45 degrees to its warp (vertical) and weft (horizontal) threads it is referred to as "true bias." That being said this is a stunning table and one I would be proud to own.

Denim....if you can use denim then you can use any type of fabric, I wonder what carbon fiber sheets would look like or carpet grass sheets if you could even run that thru a planer???!!!
The denim fibers poke thru after its ran thru the planer as the epoxy doesn't get into the actual fiber it covers it but doesn't absorb all the way thru each and every fiber thus when you plane it or sand it the exposed fibers pop up!

I‚Äôm reminded of a Little House on the Prairie episode. Probably one of two I watched in my lifetime-because the father was a woodworker as well as a farmer.   Charles was hand making tables. Along came a supposed customer who purchased one, broke it down and mass produced it for far less money-putting Charles out of business because his craftsmanship couldn‚Äôt compete with the crapsmanship of mass production.   IKEA or someone in China will probably watch this video. And because it‚Äôs manufacturable and not relying on precious slabs of wood, they will copy it. I think I would use different thicknesses for the wooden pucks the next time. The different heights of the bumps would give you a variable look to the Damascus grain in the field of the table, and likely would cut back on the psychedelic swirling throughout. Just a thought.

Actually patern welded steel is called damascus at this day and age, language changes and progresses, Arabian monosteel that was known as damascus is now mostly called wutz. Patern welded steel, that vaguely resembles wutz, which looks that way because steel was completely liquified and was floving and bubbling, completely overtook the term damascus in modern vernacular. Hate all you want, I was the one picking players, not the one being picked!

A thought on why the table /might/ get "fuzzy" again, even though it's infused with resin: it kind of reminds me of sanding 3D printed plastic with a low-grit sand paper, ike below 200. It roughens up the surface so much and so "uneven" that it also feels "fuzzy". Maybe the combination of denim + resin has a similar reaction. Despite your warning and threat of banishment I must point out that the metalworking technique that your table most resembles is NOT Damascus but the Japanese practice of Mokume - game which uses dissimilar metal sheets heated and hammered together and then sanded to reveal a woodgrain pattern. Denim Oooh, that sheetrock thing, I've gotten the opposite, I've been using generic drywall before and the person corrected me "that is clearly sheetrock"
It is getting fuzzy, because by sanding, you expose all the small fibres of the fabric. Never made an epoxy denim table, but epoxy builds for car hifi stuff. I always loved to use these thick winter bed cheats for the first layer of the object (speaker enclosure) and I always got the fuzzy feeling, after giving it a rough sanding to make the next layer of woven fibre glas stick better. If I used that kind of fabric for very small stuff, I always had to give it a thin layer of epoxy, before prepping for painting. Same as you did here. EDIT: I think an ebonized oak base with a vinegar+steel wool sollution would be an ever nicer fit. EDIT2: 30:05 is 100% the cooky monster
Whenever I have to put smaller pieces on my router table, my favorite method is to attach them to larger pieces. if you don't need one side, you can screw them down and remove them later. If you need both sides, you can either use a double-stick tape that you know you can remove later, or glue with a sheet or 2 of newspaper between that separates pretty easily when you're done. If you end up with a scrap piece too big and it becomes unstable, you can always glue another piece or 2 of material with the same thickness as the workpiece on opposite corners to make more points to balance on and a wider frame.
I appreciate what you're trying to do... I've tried to do it myself. I've lost all hope though. We're so GD addicted to correcting people that it's extremely monetizable. Try to watch 5 YouTube shorts in a row without coming across one that has a mistake so glaring you think there's no way they didn't know what they were doing... It's because almost all of them know exactly what they're doing. Go look through the comments and 40% of them are correcting the mistake and 40% more are letting the fools know they're just feeding the algorithm and encouraging propagation of incorrect information because we react to it, giving more views, more interactions, and more money to the lazy creators. Ironically, THEY THEMSELVES are not only also feeding the algorithm, but falling to the EXACT same trap. They want to correct the person who's correcting the content. Letting them know they were mistaken, the content creator didn't need to know the correct information because it was intentionally incorrect. Only about 20% of them have any actual, unique ideas if even that.

Denim! i am no woodworker nor am i a denim epoxy guru (also not sure if you‚Äôve found out already) HOWEVER - regarding the fuzziness of the denim tops after planing/sanding i believe the reason is regardless of how ‚Äòinfused‚Äô you get the epoxy with the denim you‚Äôre not altering the composition of the denim itself - you‚Äôre only saturating the cotton fibres and replacing the very tiny pockets of air with epoxy - so cutting across the fully dried epoxy denim slab (or planing or sanding it or whatever) especially when there‚Äôs no way to guarantee all the pieces of denim are completely parallel to each other, will sometimes make it so the last layer that was ‚Äòplaned‚Äô (idk terminology so bear with me) will have some spots where the last material to be removed was some epoxy and/or some denim, exposing some of the cotton fibres. This is my fairly accurate guess. I LOVE THE TABLE!

üëå perfect
As a machinist, and hobby epoxy worker, I've experimented with denim micarta before. I've wanted to try ever since I saw Peter Brown make a denim bracelet years ago.   He said the same thing you did in his video. Even though the denim fibers are fully impregnated with epoxy, once cut the surface becomes soft to the touch.  I believe this is caused by the fibers being flexible. As the cutting tool takes a chip off the epoxy, the fibers are torn and some remain sticking out of the workpiece.   When I made my worry stones out of the denim blanks I kept this feel because I thought it was unique. But after seeing how much darker and vibrant the tabke became once you covered the fibers agian, I think you made the right choice in doing so. Plus with it being a table that might experience liquid spills, I don't think it would be a good idea to have exposed cotton fibers hanging around.
Denim for sure! I loved it ‚ù§
Denim. Great job!
That's not damascus That's denimscus
constructive criticism: you should have made the wood pieces that you used to give it form a bit more varied in thickness so there's more than one bottom layer that gets exposed and covered again. idk if I'm explaining properly but having all pieces of wood equally tall, and then plaining the epoxy denim will always show the same layer up in the middle of those pieces. also making all edges equally round will provoke the same thickness of pattern on all the table. for your next project I'd suggest carving those edges and those thickness manually without any measurement so the end result has a little bit more variation and looks closer to damascus steel patterns
You are a mediocre wood worker at best...

Denim for sure! This might be the first time I can offer real advice for you too. The reason the resin dosnt soak all the way though it seems is because denium and other materials like canvas have lots and lots of tiny little tubes that takes a lot to get resin inside. Unless you can get an even stronger vaccume or get more resin between each layer it‚Äôs just a little unavoidable.   The other thing to note about the fuzziness is most micartas which is basically what this is use phenolic resin. I believe it just sets a touch ‚Äòharder‚Äô but it‚Äôs way worse for humans.
It's good to see when it works but the experiment is the excitement of the video. And when it sometimes fails you can also learn a lot... It's important to know how not to do because a wrong step can ruin ten good steps you had done before..
I prefer wood but you do make denim look great. I also agree the finished look was pretty bold and perhaps a touch over the top. I'm sure there is a buyer out there that will think this is the tits, though. Great job.

Depending on the level of depth in your molds while doing the bagging process you may want to utilize pleats or pleating .Its where you add strategic extra creases of bag material so you don‚Äôt get bridging or a spot where you get excess pooling of resin. This is a method used in composite layups for aircraft.  also it is good practice to cut out some breather and layer it under your vacuum port so you don‚Äôt suck up resin in your vacuum port ,once that happens it will most likely never work again . Things I learned in product development @ cirrus aircraft.

Hey Cam. Your bagging technique is good. One thing I'd add is a doubled up stringer of the cotton breather under the valve running over the project. It helps soak up any extra resin so it doesn't ruin the valve. I worked with carbon fiber and fiberglass for nearly a decade. Also, if you're bagging something with lots of angles like this, a few "dog ears" would help a ton!  Huge fan of the channel. I live in Scappoose and pass Goby regularly. I'd also like to come to your classes, just trying to find time between owning a business and family time. Keep up the good work and we will keep watching!

At 26:22, if you want the pillowy rounding and the bottoms of the corner don't need to be square, you can get good results from rounding the corners before you round the edges. Wouldn't have worked in this case since it was flush and the bottom frame was not rounded, but just an fyi to anyone reading.  Sometimes the order you do things in can matter.
If your Damascus police want to be truly technical, we can no longer make true Damascus due to the fact that the material, make, and process has been lost to time. Therefore we use the term o describe the pattern type. Either way, craft on and let the others sit down. I dont see their videos coming up in the algorithm.
The way I learned to router small pieces is to lay an old piece of carpet pad on a workbench, place your piece on that, then use a handheld router to go around it. Take a little at a time with multiple passes, take too much and it will try to bite it and throw it across the room. Getting your fingers that close on a router table is sketchy - which you already know because you were hesitant to do it. Listen to your gut, if it feels sketchy, think of a better way. You can get free leftover scraps of carpet pad at any carpet store. They also work well to lay pieces on when sanding, do a pretty good job of preventing the sander from trying to walk the piece around the workbench.

Denim! It looks like you really improved on the process mess of the last table and I don't know if I left this comment or not, but: as a seamstress, fabric upcyclers are always AWASH in scrap denim, and, I think this pattern-welded cotton-poly method might lend itself really well to using scrap denim. I would absolutely love to see you source upcycled denim for your next go instead of using new. As to your question about softness- to me that's a testament to the epoxy effectiveness. You're encapsulating the fibers, but replacing them. When you tear a fabric fiber it always wants to pull the individual threads away from the weave of the fabric now that it's no longer held. However in this case you're exposing millions of thread ends  oriented upwards, but since they're still  encased in the weave, they have no where to go. You get micrometers of movement in those rougher planer cuts, and it's soft. As a baby wood worker and very decent seamstress who loves fabric..... I really want to touch it... üòÖ
The denim finish reminds me almost of carbon fiber. I think that would be a cool new project to undergo, layered carbon fiber epoxy table.

Denim. Without boring you too much with molecular science, the reason it's still "fuzzy", is because the resin can permeate the denim weave no problem, but it can't fully permeate the cotton fibers, which are mostly cellulose - even more so than wood. so you'll understand how resin can't fully penetrate it

It's fuzzy after the epoxy because its pully fine fibers that too small to be noticeably impregnated with expoxy. Its long been a benefit of micarta that it remains grippy when wet and worn which is why its often used for knife handles.

About what you said with people correcting you on the Damascus thing etc. The thing is that your right it doesn't matter 99% of the time, with Damascus and other things like it, when there's barely any difference between one thing and the other. BUT there are times when it does consistently matter:  1. When you are explaining what it is, you should at least acknowledge that there are different terms with minor differences. ESPECIALLY when it's educational.  2. When it is about a product that you are selling you should always use the most correct term possible. I don't know you or that Damascus situation enough to give you shit for it, but it looks like you do both to some degree at least.

Acknowledging the no need to correct terms generally used for things, I would still point out that this is actually micarta, if only to make sure that people can find similar applications easier and also potentially people who've found issues before (mostly with knife scales). Though, some people do also further break the patterns down into damascus micarta and marble micarta (with some even further implying a third more consistent micarta like your last denim table or Jonny's paper table, though those both fall short of the brand-name product Micarta, though also way exceeding the size).  I don't have any experience with micarta myself, so I can't answer the question about the texture thing, but there may be knife-makers who could (especially since those are meant to be held in the hand, and working at a smaller scale means you can be that much better about getting it completely saturated).  Oh, and micarta is fully stable (and one of the easier to make but still decent quality stabilized scale materials), so the "as far as I know" is definitely correct in regards to not needing to leave room for any movement (it doesn't shrink or expand from UV, heat, moisture, age, etc. at all).

Just a heads up, I generally like your snarky comments (like the ones about the guy correcting damascus), but for some reason the one about "if you get hurt it's just more entertainment for me" came off as a little smug.  We all do stuff in the shop that is against best practices, whether it's wearing flip flops or holding your hand way too close to a spinning router bit. People are dumb, they see an 'expert' like you doing something and may think that it's okay for them. There are skill and comfort levels. You can get away with sketchy router technique because you've done it a bunch of times. They might take their finger off. I'm not the youtube safety police, but denigrating someone who potentially mimics your technique and winds up hurt comes off a little smug.  Anyway given how you typically respond to comments in your videos, I hope this doesn't fall on deaf ears. I understand that having a mob of people correcting and critiquing every little thing you do is probably irritating. However, it's the name of the game when you're a public figure.  *off my soap box*

Deep into DiWhy territory.
It gets fuzzy because the epoxy is brittle while the fabric is flexible, and you have to think about this at the scale of a fiber, not at the macro scale.  When you try to cut the material (sanding, planing, whatever) you're applying a stress to the composite material. Since the epoxy is brittle, it'll tend to "fail" and be removed anywhere you apply force. The fabric doesn't necessarily "fail" at the same time as the epoxy, and it could fail in other places once it's freed of the epoxy (like somewhere in the middle of a saw kerf, instead of on both ends). Now you're simply applying stress to fabric which will tend to move out of the way and fray instead of simply being cut. This leaves you with tiny little tails of epoxy-free fibers poking out of the composite panel. The same thing happens with carbon fiber, although it feels quite different.  You can either shave the fuzzy surface to remove the protruding fabric, or you have to apply a wash coat of epoxy to re-coat those loose fiber ends.
YES! So glad you revisited the denim table.
Speaking from a perspective of composites manufacturing (your denim tables are sort of a version of what would be considered a "pre-preg 2D layup PMC"), the reason it gets fuzzy when you sand/cut it is because of dry spots. In other words, the epoxy isn't fully saturating every fiber in the fabric. It's more likely just coating the fibers. So, as soon as you cut it, these exposed fiber edges are still just fiber, without any resin holding them together. It doesn't really matter, though, because you're not trying to get "full strength" capability from your finished product, and you're skim coating it when you're done, anyway. A true pre-preg material would have each layer fully infused with resin, usually through a pressurized process.  If you go to the vacuum bag infusion process (where you vacuum down the dry layup and then suck in the epoxy), you will likely get better infusion of the resin into the fiber.

The sheer force of the planer against the infused fibers of the denim breaks the epoxy off of the fibers leaving the fuzzy feel for the top couple micrometers.
More denim projects; truly unique.
I would like to see more experiments with denim and epoxy!  Question: would you consider using rolls or smaller cuts of denim to form the regions that're exposed when you send it through the plainer? I think you could get some interesting shapes that way (granted i really like the psychedelic look of this table, but it might not be psycedelic enough for me, ha).  Also I have a hypothesis about the way it gets "fuzzy" when sanded...denim is a pretty dense twill weave fabric - i imagine it doesn't perfectly absorb epoxy all the way through. The vacuum bag process helps it absorb evenly, but i think the return to a fabric feel is due to tiny, imperceptible voids in the fibers. Will you experiment with other fabrics to test it? You could try a looser weave and/or a thin cotton fabric to see if you have a similar result.

Denim
the fuzziness is because the epoxy holds the fibers in place but the microscopic unevenness of the sanding means you release & pull some fibers up, the epoxy COATS the fibers and doesn't actually infuse through them completely.  due to this reason it's similar effect to watering wood after sanding the first time.   grab a cheap microscope to look at under & you should see what happens much better while also making a awesome shot.

The fuzziness could be from 1. wicking effect with fibers, 2. mild epoxy shrinkage, or my best guess... 3. "micro" tear out like when sanding wood and the sublayers can't take the abrasion. It's just that maybe you're using fabric instead of wood. ?

Denim! You could also experiment with different colors and weights of denim. Also, there is a specific resin that can be used to infuse in porous surfaces. You put it in a vacuum chamber to pull the air out and let the resin really get into the weave of the fabric. Then, stack it wet with the regular resin and do the vacuum bag. Nice tableü§©, wet layup is the way to go! Please Do Not try epoxy infusion! It will be close to impossible to do it to that long and thick table. You might be able to do it with 2 to 5 fabricks. Allso you will need atleast 0.85bar of vacuum to it to work. I think that the fabric is fusy after cutting is bechause the individual fibers are not complitely saturated with te resin. Bechause denim yarn is so tightly twirled, Only the outside of the yarn is saturated leaving the core dry. When cut, you expose the dry yarn. Allso the epoxy is weaker and more britle than the linen fibre, and when cut the epoxy breaks clean and is just scraped of the linen untill the linen breaks.

NO! STOP IT Damascus is not a proper name for traditional Damascus ripple patterns. It's just the lazy modern one. Hell, the WHOLE modern "Damascus " movement & naming results from a a trademark manipulation to make money of the most respected historical blades lost to the industrial revolution; what is now called " Damascus Wootz". That prick has destroyed the history of that name, destroyed the history & high art of Complex, beautiful, detailed patterns in traditional Pattern Welding (the proper name of the western art). He too western pattern welding methods, used them badly on purpose, and made blanks that would fool most hobbyist collectors.  Called it Damascus (trademark) to scam collecting.  HE went under. Then American blacksmiths As a whole decided the scam was too good to pass up, rebranded pattern welding, and never bothered to even try to look like the original. The sheer Amount of utter bullshit here. Please either Acknowledge the actual history,  or stay away from it. Modern American "Damascus" is cultural appropriation of the worst form; like British follies in retro Roman style. Or Chinese sweat factories selling "ancient swordss" they made yesterday.
Super cool project. You would probably get a more natural and pleasing pattern if you used some large smooth river rocks for the form instead of the plywood. here is how you drill holes correctly How to Use a Drill Power up your drill. Adjust the torque to suit the material you're drilling.  Find the Xs or dots you made to mark where to drill. Get at the correct level to drill the hole.  Stabilize your drill vertically.  Gently pull the trigger.  Once you've drilled as far as you need, put the drill in reverse.

That is not Damascus, it is just good old fashion pattern welding. Damascus is a very specific type of crucible steel that came out of India and was exported to Damascus Syria where it was fashioned into weapons during the late medieval period. By the time of the Early Modern period the specific supply was lost, and no more has been made since. Pattern welding has been practiced since at least roman times. There are some very good examples of Germanic and Viking weapons with patterns. China, Japan, and Korea all have examples. My favorite are the old black powder shotgun barrels that came out of Belgium in the late 1800's. The so called rediscovery of Damascus Steel in the 70's is nothing but bullshit marketing.  The reason this should be corrected is because the original meaning of the word is totally different than the new usage. And causes confusion. You may feel that it is cool or ok to interchangeable use the term for two totally different things. But you are wrong. Unlike your sheet rock/Dry wall example where they are the same thing, in this case they are not. Both metallurgically, and in the construction of the base object.
Term Damascus is only used for Damascus Steel, that's it, did anyone ever heard Damascus Iron, Damascus Copper or Damascus Aluminum,i think this is the end of all the illetrat arguments peoples puting hereüòÇ
i love it!
I believe Damascus is the original pattern welded steel. Named after the city in ancient times so your right . Great Damascus table don't like the base id stub my toes on it
it's not too thick for vacuum infusion -- vacuum pressure is an incredibly strong force. If you're at 25 psi on a 3' by 5' surface, that's 50,000 pounds+ of force over the entire surface

Damascus inspired denim table, that should shut up the naysayers  To get the true look you‚Äôre looking for. I would use all three denims I would cut the links to the link you want them and then slice each one into 1 inch strips then I would weave them in and out in a three color pattern, changing out both directions as you weave them together. Have them would be stripped down the height and half would be stripped down the length then you weave them in and out of each other just stapling the end pieces to each one, so you pull it Tire lays like you want to. It would also allow the denim to form into more detailed shapes. If you wanted, it would make a great Damascus inspired denim table.

Denim... to make a "true" Damascus-style, you could try throwing the denim on sort of randomly, as opposed to laying it in large, flat sheets. Toss a bunch of smaller, randomly-sized pieces and let them fall as they may. THEN do the vacuum sealing and see if it presses down flat-ish. Also, maybe cover the vacuum-sealed conglomeration with sheets of plywood or sheetrock and lay weights on top of those to really press it flat. Or, instead of denim, throw down a bunch of differently colored wood veneers.

Hi Cam! Composite tech/engineer here! I loved the look of the table and love seeing you expand your skillset working with new meterials! Cant wait to see what you do with carbon fiber one of these days! So a couple things that would help greatly help with the layup, there is a HUGE difference between peel ply, and release film. Peel ply is intended to be directly on the wet fabric and is intended to be peeled of leaving a somewhat textured/matte but leveled surface free of resin wrinkles. HOWEVER! Perforated release film (for pre-impregnated fabrics use non perforated film) is supposed to go on top of the peel ply so it doesnt bond to your breather which is why you had a difficult time peeling it off. Release film peels exactly how Saran wrap would like you were talking about In addition, you end up losing a lot of resin in the process and can resin starve your part which could have also contributed to the fibers doing weird things. When doing your next table/project, the ideal ratio is 60/40 weight fabric to resin, that should help guessing how much resin to use without wasting as much. I also use a bondo scrapper because i found it easier to saturate the fabric easier. Lastly, for a wet layup, you dont need to have a catch bin because ideally you have the necessary amount of resin within your bag and any excess resin will get soaked into the breather through the perforated release film. Thank for listening to my Ted Talk and cant wait to see the future projects!
Cam your imagination is the only thing that could hold you back at this point. Use it and show the world some fun new ways to make things outside the norm. Not to say, stop with the wood stuff, I think we all still love that. And as long as you are having fun, that's all that really matters. Love your stuff. Good luck.
by saying that list is comprehensive you're suggesting that it's ok to correct you about any items not on the list.
Please wear a proper mask when sanding denim. Workers in denim factories get silicosis from denim dust. You really don't want that. Also look up Byssinosis from inhaling cotton dust.

DENIM! I don‚Äôt work with epoxy much but I am a fashion designer, your concern with the denim may have to do with the fabric content. A lot of low to mid range denim fabrics tend to have some spandex or similar materials and those don‚Äôt soak as easily as cotton. That may account for the fuzz you experience. A higher quality 100% cotton denim may eliminate that problem. You could also try a lighter Oz fabric or a chambray fabric. Thinner will give you a more even soak. I hope this may help in the future! Loooooove the experiments you do!
Denim
My bet for the fuzziness and softer feel is that even though there is so much resin, the material itself is still present, and denim is cotton after all. It will present some fuzziness when ground up, since resin starts to lose its strenght and at that point you feel the denim's own feel. Kinda like shaving down wood

If you don't like that sharp edge on your corner after doing your router run, then next time you make a table round the corners on your rectangle to the same radius as your routing edge. Then you'll end up with a nice smooth spherical octant instead of a corner.

Denim. You can make denim maps of countries/states or popular damascus patterns like raindrop and ladder... endless possibilities for custom orders.
Very cool table! Damascus, or Patterned steel, is a process of folding and hammering/stretching out the material, usually steel. The process of layering different materials, working a pattern that is revealed by removing material other than steel is commonly referred to as the Japanese method Mukami-Gani.  Either way, it's very cool.

Got an idea about why the denim is fuzzy: When you buy a brand new pair of jeans (or other fabrics), there¬¥s still some kind of coating on the fibers (probably to have it run through the machines better) If you¬¥ve ever spilled some water on unwashed fabric, it doesn¬¥t soak in immediately, it often even runs off. This effect goes away after the first wash.  With epoxy it may be the same, the epoxy in general bonds well to the fabric, but not to individual fibers.

For those that always correct people when they use the brand name as the generic name, use caution because you could both be correct in some cases. When a brand name becomes ubiquitous with the actual product name, often their trademark rights are removed and all products can be legally called that. This is why Google is actively promoting to not use their name to describe online searching. They could lose ownership of their own name.

Correction: as an expert in Denim for 25 yrs in the fabric making business, those are not different color washes, rather they are different color shades. Denim washes are only if the fabric actually gets a wash using water, or a combination of chemicals to take the color lighter, or darker. Your shades, are yarns dyed at different colors of lightness, then woven into fabric as the warp meets the weft. I am sorry if you'll hate me forever and bruised your soul a bit. Yes your disclaimer was you wear the same man pants for 10 years. Also, wast that woodworking, craft, or experiment?Surely was not a trend for home use. Cheers!

Denim is a good look. To each their own though, I do prefer a high gloss on my tables but other than that it turned out great! The one thing I was hoping for was that the denim would keep its light color but I don't know how that would work with the other layers of wax/epoxy/3m protectant applied to it. Amazing work and yes I see the Damascus within the denim.
TL:DR look into how to *stabilize* cloth etc. with stabilizing epoxy, which is thinner, long-curing, and involves cycling the pressure if you can. Getting the epoxy into all the tiniest bits is different than just coating or dunking it too, and; though not hard; can take a long while.  I would think it's getting fuzzy when cut b/c the fibers are separating the epoxy into microscopic granules in much the same way some ice trays make a bunch of ice cubes connected by a thin sheet of ice on top. when you cut into it, any isolated and now-free epoxy bits fall away. This would also mean you're not infusing the cloth as thoroughly as you think you are.  I really have to suggest that you try making a pour mold again. make a 3-4" deep melamine box, then layer in your cloth, covering it generously in epoxy as you go, this will ensure that there's nowhere for the epoxy to go that's not IN the cloth, defeating it's want to drain out via gravity. once you've built your layers and made your pattern, make sure the whole block of cloth is covered in epoxy, just as if you were doing a regular, poured-epoxy table.  in order to ensure that the cloth is fully infused, down into the finest of fibers, there are a few things you can try. 1st is to use thinner to make the epoxy pour as close to water-thin as you can. thin epoxy, with slow hardener, should give gravity and atmospheric pressure all they need to get the job done: the drawback will be that it'll have to sit in a corner to cure for a few MONTHS. (some epoxy's, when poured in this manner, are weaker and even brittle, when cured, so building the project on a 1/2" lexan sheet; well coated in clear adhesive; to act as the underside of the tabletop should make it plenty strong/durable.)

Denim  That's a very rare wooden table there, the tree  is called denimithius its only found in the parks in Levi and Lee and wrangler counties on the east coast. All the rest that is found are hybrid trees called denimwannabe which are strung throughout the U.S. and mainly China and Asia so you have to watch out for those fakes because some can be very convincing.

Denim is flexible, epoxy is mostly brittle, when the epoxy is cut away some of the denim fibers tear out and remain attached, never worked with denim specifically, but other natural fiber composites work similarly

As someone who has dabbled in composite materials - the denim-epoxy material is a composite - like carbon fiber. Those fibers don't move smoothly with the material and tend to behave differently with regards to cutting and sanding. They can flex out of the way and you just cut/pull away the epoxy but the fiber tips don't cut. They're flexible localize strong-points in the material, so you get those fibers sticking out just a little - making it fuzzy.
Denim.  Would love to see more.
cool table idea. i like doing things differently just for the sake of doing them. who knows, maybe this will be the newest trend, like those idiots who buy pants with holes in them already.  14:25 be careful cutting things that are wider than they are long on a table saw with the fence trapping the wood. that can lead to things getting pinched or caught and go flying. luckily you have a cross sled there to contain things and allow your hands a good place to grab, but the stop-block was the right idea and safer. this thin piece of wood is the most extreme case of "wider than it is long" (along the direction of the cut) but still sturdy enough that if it went flying, it'd be like a bat to the face. this can happen if your fence is tighter to the blade as you progress along the cut, causing a pinch and ultimately creating a missile.  not a big deal on this cut, but it's a dangerous habit with bigger pieces.
Denim! So cool and beautiful
What I think is happening with the table becoming soft after sanding, is that the epoxy is penetrating between the fibers, but not completely inside of them. They get partially ripped out of the epoxy and stick up as fuzzy little hairs.

Its worth noting that you arent using denim. Denim is a trademarked name by the E.W. Jameson Company who invented the warped-faced cotton textile back in 1856. This is also complete bullshit.

To embrace the soft fuzziness, make a game table! As long as you incorporate an easy clean area for cups and snack it would be perfect for card games and tabletop games like d&d‚ù§
Denim. I work with fabric and that the denim becomes fuzzy even after it is "saturated" doesn't surprise me. All fabric is made of strands  or threads and is woven together. Denim is classified by weight the heavier the weight the thicker the fibers. I think denim strands are also coated to make them Denim plus the dye, it sits on top of the denim. So when you are "saturating" the denim it is only the outer threads that are getting saturated, the inner threads are still untouched. Then with the sanding you get the fuzzies or the inner threads being exposed. This is not a professional observation, I wasn't surprised when you mentioned the fuzzy feeling it made total sense to me and I am just trying to work it out in my own head.

This is by no means too thick for VARTM process.  The setup process takes a little bit, and time to allow it to fully pull down to vacuum, but it is worth it with the quality of the product you get at the end.  You should allow it to fully pull down with no resin, then perform a leak check monitoring over at least 30 min to verify no leaks.  Then you can perform them resin transfer.
Denim feels fuzzy because you cannot 100% impregnate epoxy in between the microstrands that make up the twisted strands, which are woven together to form the denim.  You have epoxy between these twisted strands, but not necessarily inside of them.

The denim goes fuzzy because the the denim is flexable and the expoxy is now. For example, when you were a young lad and you put a bucket load of gel in your hair to impress the ladies at the disco. You would then load up the hair spray to make sure it wasn't going to budge throughout the evening. As a evening went on the gel would start to crack and break away from your hair and the exposed hair was soft and flexable again. Similar to the expoxy, you are just knocking off the expoxy from the denim strands and leaving those strands exposed.  How this helps, great video by the way! i think it would be great to see a mixture of different denim colours or maybe even different materials in the mix?  Cheers, Will.

Cam, I don‚Äôt know if you have seen these for router dust collection before, but you should take a look at the Betterley Stacc-Vac router base for a dust collection system. I would stack it against the Festool fatboy router for dust collection anyday. Since it is just the base you can mount any router that you want, which is a huge advantage over that monster top heavy Festool 2200. I would suggest ordering the router base with 2 dust deflectors which will allow you to use even your tallest edge profile bit and still be able to catch probably 98.5% of the router dust (my guess). I think that you would be impressed with this solution. And the best part is that Betterley Tools are made in the USA, actually in Minnesota.

Denim.   To answer the question, of why the sanded epoxy denim fells furry, maybe look at sample under a microscope.   I suspect it is small epoxy infused fibres that are standing up, like a the soft bristle of a quality hair brush or soft broom.

beautiful
@20:30 as far as the table being fuzzy, i would wager its one (or both) of two things. either youre not getting a full saturation in the fabric. otherwise the individual fibers wouldnt be loose enough to be fuzzy. taka an off cut and look at it under a microscope to be sure. OR... its similar to fiber glass. when you break it you see indivifual fibers even with a proper layup. deffinately go with the vacumme infusion rout. its not any more difficult than what youre doing now and it will save you an entire day of wetting out the denim. Edit: this isnt new really, if you look at knife scales that are made in a similar fasion, the courser material (like demin or canvas) all have a bit of texture to them if they arent treated and coated. its popular for better grip.

No Denim. Not sure if making these tables is worth the effort OTHER THAN the sole purpose of making a YouTube video out of it. Basically, the content IS THE PRODUCT. Denim.  It looks absolutely amazing!
the table is fuzzy because it is made of fuzz. Just like the wood can still splinter (though not as easily) the jeans can still be fuzzy (just not easily).  I would make a little test surface with one of those offcuts to see how cool the fuzzy finish holds up. My instincts tell me that fuzzy table wouldn't be cool- but the coolest stuff is often counter-intuitive.  This table is cool though. Since a failed fuzzy table could just be turned into one of these- maybe you make a fuzzy table- then use it at the shop for a couple of years to "wear it in"- then you can polish it up and sell it for more- just like worn jeans can cost more.

Denim. Might already be commented or what you‚Äôre thinking for your next one, but I‚Äôd say yes to less trippy and to make the next one more like wood grain. The way to do this would seem to be to have much more gradual slopes on your forms and way less forms. I think it would be much more visually pleasing if all of the forms were going vertically and there were less lines around each form exposed. I think this would mean a form that might be as tall, but would be much wider and have a really gradual slope.

I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you‚Äôre referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I‚Äôve recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX. Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called ‚ÄúLinux‚Äù, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project. There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine‚Äôs resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called ‚ÄúLinux‚Äù distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

Denim Best guess on fuzzy feeling surface, is that many of the denim fibers were not completely saturated with epoxy.  Surface encapsulation would release the fibers upon sanding as the shell of epoxy flakes off.   Another possibility would be that very thin epoxy filaments around individual denim threads are just very flexible.  The way to test this theory would be to take one of your edge off cuts and put it under a microscope.

YOUR FIBRE FRAYING QUESTION EXPLAINED AND IDEAS! The epoxy has a high viscosity.  When you are  making a vacuum chamber for a project like this, you are essentially compressing the project.  Having the project in a vacuum is the same as putting the project into a sealed room at high pressure.  Because the inside is a vacuum, the ambient pressure outside is pushing the epoxy into the denim.  You don't have enough external pressure / enough internal vacuum to drive the epoxy completely into the denim fibres.  With this, you will have unglued fibres, and when you sand them down, they fray.   If you want to have deeper penertation of your epoxy, you can consider the following options, each one a bit more elaborate than the previous:   -Have a stronger vacuum -Make your denim VERY dry before assembling which will allow the epoxy to wick into it more effectively -Have a less viscous epoxy so it seeps into the fibres more effectively. - Compression by water column - Have a higher pressure environment for your project while you are vacuuming it.  To do this, you would need a tall water chamber and you would need to prevent the project from floating up.  Vacuum the project, and when you have reached about the max vacuum you can reach, add water. 33" of water is equal to 1 pound per square inch.  It's not a lot, you would probably want at least 6' of water to make any difference, but it would help, and it would be a crazy project to watch!  - Compression by submersion - Tie it to a big rock and chuck it in a deep lake.  Drag it up a week or 2 later - This would be so entertaining, especially if it worked!  What a fun story for a product origin!  The deeper the water, the higher the compression.  You just have to bear in mind the curing temperature of the epoxy and the water temperature. - Hydraulic Press - Press your project with external mechanical force.  Maybe a local hydraulic pressing channel collab.  Vacuum your project, have it in a tray, put a material on top of it which would not leak past the seal and would conform to the project shape.  This could be sand, sawdust, or another material that would corm to the shape of the project.  You could test this on a  2' x 2' or 3' x 3'  project to see if it works, and if it does, you could probably find someone with a press that could do the job of a bigger project.  This would also be very cool to watch. - Pressure Chamber - You could get a chamber built that was the size you wanted (4'6 x 8'6 if you want to do full plywood sheet sizes), and make it air tight.  Vacuum your project, and then hook a compressor up to the air space and compress it.  This would likely be the easiest way to do extreme vacuuming/pressing without needing to have expensive hydraulic equipment.  Have something that can support even just 80-100psi and it will put on a huge squeeze on your project.  That would be cool wicked cool too.

Denim! I am most definitely entertained! Also I think I learned some things as well!  In the world of composites, soaking/injecting the layers of fiber (carbon fiber, fiberglass, or whatever composite material you are using, denim in this case) in a thermoset matrix (generally polymer, epoxy in this case) and then laying it up on the mould, is called prepeg (or dry layup sometimes). It is much cleaner than putting the layers together first and then soaking it in the resin; this is often referred to as wet layup. Terms are often used interchangeably, and I'm not sure of them exactly either. This just what I remember from class and the short job I had at one point.  You have effectively made a composite table, as opposed to plastic, wood, or metal. We live in the future man. Possibilities are endless! üòÇüëç

As a painter, I've tried getting my canvases smooth by priming & sanding, priming & sanding, but it never really gets any smoother, even though the primer fully soaks into the fabric. Without a microscope there's no way to tell what's really going on, but my belief is that there's a kind of 'bloating' which occurs when fabric soaks up liquid, then the fibers will naturally 'remember' their original shape which creates microscopic air gaps during the drying process. As the fabric is sanded, it exposes the tiny holes where the once-expanded fibers tried to stick out from the surface. These new holes will allow the fabric to absorb more liquid in the next pass, the bloating occurs again & the process repeats itself.

What fun!  In jewelry we have a process of melting many layers of different metals together in much the same way, right down to the "bumps that create the textures. In the jewelry context, this process has a japanese name: mokume gane  (mock-ooo-may gone- ay)

Denim, I mean micarta!  So I guess you are actually making micarta in reality.  Micarta is a composite formed from layers of a substrate (cloth, paper, and carbon fiber, to name a few) compressed and set in resin.   If you left it raw and fuzzy, it will patina over time, just look at micarta knife handles that will age and patina as the oils and dirt add to the look.  Great job sir... üëçü§†

To do small pieces use a hand router. Take a piece of wood drive a few small nails through so they just poke out the other side. Then hammer your small pieces of wood onto the points and router. No issues with fingers. Or pieces flying off.
Technically, what you have here isn‚Äôt actually denim. Denim originally came from N√Æmes, France, and was called ‚ÄúSerge de N√Æmes‚Äù, from which the term ‚Äúdenim‚Äù originates. You‚Äôre welcome.

Looks grearüòä
Pretty Ugly not gonna lie, lol. but still great talent!
Interestingly enough the knifemaking community uses similar materials, the name brand is "Micarta", and the homebrew versions are basically exactly what you've done here, a natural fiber-based fabric (or paper) and stabilizing resin compressed and saturated. It's a preferred material for knife handles for some people specifically because the outer layer stays "fuzzy" if un-finished, it helps maintain grip when being used in damp/sweaty conditions. There are some absolutely crazy patterns that people have come up with, one of my favorites was always a high contrast twist, which almost looks like wood grain at the end. The paper versions can get absolutely insane with people using cri-cuts to add custom inclusions (like what you did with the wood deformation mold pieces), embedding finely shredded "confetti" style paper and other nutty methods. It's all really neat and opens a crazy level of customization, but as you mentioned in the video you're probably one of the first to have taken it to such an extreme as doing whole tables. Can't wait to see what you come up with next!
20:38 could make for an excellent card table if left fuzzy like that.   most likely much more durable than the felt they usually use anyway.

About your plywood forms: Don't just quarter-round the edges but instead sand the thickness to a taper from the edge to the center of each form. This will make your planed off "topo" lines variable like a "topo map". I think this would increase the look of it being more organic rather than engineered.

The fuzziness is probably either because the denim absorbs the epoxy slowly an initial saturation isn‚Äôt the ‚Äú24hr‚Äù saturation or whatever.   Or when sanding, no matter the amount of saturation, fibres are prised out of the composite matrix and hence becomes fuzzy after sanding

My thoughts on the fuzzy top is like shaving with a blunt razor or gardening using busted old lawn mower. The denim is cotton which is thin long fibers with good tensile strength, flexible and resistance to shear forces, whilst the epoxy cures as a homogeneous crystalline type structure which is brittle to shear forces. So when the planer blade is sheering off layers the denim fibers but bend and deflect under the blade while epoxy shears off cleanly, so denim is slightly crushed and the infused epoxy crumbles out while fibers sitting proud of the planed epoxy surface.

Tablesaw safety: You should never use the fence and a sled/miter gauge at the same time.¬† Reason: If the piece tweaks even slightly it can get jammed between the blade and the fence and kickback hurting you or the saw or both.¬† Solution: Set a stop block at the beginning of the fence so that you'll come off it before you engage the cut.  ** I certain Cam knows this and that little 1.5x1.5 piece lacks the diagonal length to create much kickback, like a foot wide cabinet panel would. He's already said he's just for entertainment, but people ARE watching to learn. This comment will likely get lost in the stack, but I hope this helps someone.

Denim! More denim and go wild! Thoughts on the fuzzies: my wife makes fiber art sculptures, and stiffens porous fabric with PVA. She thins it 50/50 with water so it will penetrate the fibers better. In the case of many layers of denim, I think that the weaving process and high-pressure rolling of the finished denim creates super-dense areas where the threads cross. The epoxy might not be able to get into those areas at full viscosity. I wonder if thinning it would give more penetration and reduce the fuzzies when you're first sanding the planed block. I loved this completely surprising and gorgeous Damascus, definitely Damascus look.

I am not an expert but I think I have a theory as to why it become fuzzy again despite being infused with epoxy. Friction.  Friction creates heat, and epoxy when mixed with fabrics creatures small spike/shards to harden but at still extremely soft and breakable to the touch. As a result, you get as fuzzy texture. Let me know if I was correct in my assessment or not next time you do it in a subsequent video, I'd love to know if my theory is correct or not.

I believe the surface gets fuzzy again because when you remove material from the surface you are stripping away the relatively brittle epoxy and leaving a "5 oclock shadow" of the fibrous denim poking out from the epoxy one of the two materials has a bit more "flex" and cannot be removed as cleanly as the other
Im a carpenter. Why did you choose to make the tabletop as big as the base? Sure the top is not made of wood but the base still is and can shrink/ grow and change shape ever so slightly with changing atmospheres. The chance you get now is that after some months one of the corners of the base can stick out ever so slightly and become a very sharp point where you could hurt yourself.
