You could probably use a sheet of mylar or PET film as a release layer when vacuum molding things like this.  My theory about the epoxied cotton getting fuzzy is that the cutting surface of the planer rips the cotton instead of cutting it, which will stretch the fibers but not the cured epoxy. The epoxy surface probably micro-shatters, too, as the fibers get pulled taut and snap.

Denim. Infused with Epoxy does not equal being epoxy.  It means that all the air has been replaced with epoxy.  But when you sand that back, you expose the raw denim to the air, it will naturally feel exactly like denim(aka cotton). This is different for more fragile materials that may be burned by the exothermic reaction of epoxy hardening.  In that case those materials are hard because they burned. This is also why you need to have a complete encasing of your material with epoxy, not just an infusion.

Eh. On the corrections thing, some videos do have straight up misinformation in them and thus deserve to be corrected, for something as simple and non-important as the proper usage of the word 'Damascus'?  Yeah, you don't have to correct that, especially since it's used interchangeably as you said.

to back up that other person, and provide clarification for everyone in the comments...  damascus steel is part of what is called "watered steel" metal.  what happened is in ancient times in india, they learned they had hybrid iron mines and when they heated it up, all the "impurities" boiled off leaving just the raw pig iron.  when the smiths in the city of Damascus got it, they knew how to heat it and work the alloyed steel without heating it up and removing all those impurities, creating whats called a wootz ingot, and then turning that into blades, which eventually became known as Damascus steel.  there are many ways to achieve the same look of a watered steel blade without using wootz, most notably the japanese fold-forging or modern pattern welded billets.  it is just that calling it damascus is sexier than saying watered steel.  there are people out there that still use crucibles to make wootz ingots, it is just a lot harder and longer process.  hence most people do pattern welded billets.  cheaper and easier version.  yes, i am that person.  no, bad things will not happen to me!
Love the denim work it‚Äôs unbelievable beautiful and in unusual to the norm

More denim
The reason it‚Äôs fuzzy is because you are breaking apart the fibers of the denim. When you are pouring the epoxy onto the denim it‚Äôs not wetting it deep and penetrating it like a lower viscosity liquid would. Instead you‚Äôre probably surrounding the individual strings so when you sand/cut them the inner most core or ‚Äúdry‚Äù fibers of the thread that haven‚Äôt been wetted by the epoxy flare out like a brush or the end of a piece of Paracord.

Because we have no malicious intent and I speak from experience myself on this  matter. Think of it like an old wound which was cause by circumstances outside of your control. For some reason the wound never healed properly. Perhaps because the trauma is ongoing or to do so may have caused you more trouble at the time either way it still festers. And now as you go about your day a person might unknowingly bump into you and apply some minimal amount of pressure in the region of the festering wound causing you to cry out in considerable agony. Did that person intentionally cause you this pain? Of course not but it may appear to you that they have because the pain is very much real. But if you would only take some time to identify for yourself what might be causing you this trouble, you could find the wound, dress it correctly, tend to it until it heals and now you won‚Äôt scream in agony should another person bump into you. More denim colors, please.  Possible problems.   One:  denim is made of yarn fibers, so yes to fuzzy edges, even with embedded epoxy.  Next time, fray some denim to see the many fibers.   Two:  yes, denim expands and contracts, especially with moisture or a dry climate.  The holes drilled into the tabletop are the weak fray zone, which could cause warping.  Oops, routing the edge will add to problem number one.   love it
I really enjoy your content. Dig the stuff you build and always enjoy your commentary üòÇ.
For the soft surface I'd say: 1) if you're not doing it, try doing the proper amount of epoxy and apply it to each layer (usually you want to go for 60% fibre aka jeans to 40% resin) 2) if only the top is soft I'd say it has to do with the sanding, if the lateral faces feel soft after you cut them, you didn't use enough resin/it didn't penetrate properly  Learning pains from making a 10 layer panel of resin infused carbon fibre: - MUST make sure the bag is properly sealed - Get the proper equipment (catchpot, spiral and line clamps are crucial) - Every 20-25% of the way, close the resin feed line and let the vacuum line suck the resin for a bit - Trust the scale, don't trust when the resin seems to have reached the other end (keep it running until the epoxy in the feeding bucket is roughly the "leftover" amount you estimated at the beginning) - 10 layers of 55x30cm of 0.6mm plys took roughly 4 hours to get properly wet, so be patient -if you already know part of the layup is not going to be affected, but is just there to add thickness you can use some nomex honeycomb instead or some other core material -Probably wise to have more than one feeding point if making a whole table -besides easy composites, che out the rock west composite video

I dove into woodworking after seeing guys build slingshots out of baltic birch or Micarta/mycarta with all these neat contours that really add to the artistic element of the slingshot. Seeing this table reminds me of that, but better. I think if you did less contrast in the denim colors, but still have 3-4 shades of the same color, you could get away with more fun with the base of a table or desk since the top would be less "loud" but equally as interesting.  All in all, more denim. Oh, and Cam, your technique with rounding over the smaller pieces was precisely why you didn't have kickback or an accident. Two points of consistent pressure on the workpiece and taking your time without relaxing is what makes sketchy stuff work. Well done Sir.

This is fascinating! I can sort of answer the fuzzy question. Not trying to be one of those jerks, it's legit part of the explanation. This is a type of micarta and while the epoxy does fuse with the fabric, when you start removing layers, it will minutely break the bond on the edges leaving just the fabric. It does the same when you use paper you just don't feel it as much because the paper is so much thinner.

Try this next time. get a board and some tape. put tape on the top of the piece you're routing and the end of the stick, then use CA glue to stick them together. as long as you don't press too hard it should work, and if it doesn't, your fingers are nowhere near the blades.

I have never commented on any video on YouTube before as I am quite a private person. Having said that I wanted to point out that I have a mixture of furniture, some expensive and some from IKEA. Our furniture has travelled the world the last 20 years from Sydney to Dallas, to Paris where we moved houses 3 times and back to Sydney and the IKEA furniture has stood up to everything that has been thrown at it from trucks to trains and container ships and it is still looks as good as when we first put it together way back in the 90's. It has also survived 3 children and now several grandchildren.

Denim! Thoughts on the fuzzy feel‚Ä¶ Even when you‚Äôre infusing the epoxy you‚Äôre really only filling the void between the fibers that make up the denim. Once you plane or cut or sand the denim you‚Äôre severing the denim fibers and exposing the fiber ends that the epoxy was not able to coat. Nothing but a pretengineers guesstimate here ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Denim. Cam, As far as the feel about the fuzziness of the table, think of it this way. It‚Äôs not 100% infused. You still have the denim fibers that weren‚Äôt infused with the epoxy. The actual fibers take up space in the epoxy thus leaving the feel of the fuzziness. I hope this explains it right. You will always tell the difference between apples and oranges.

Why does it get fuzzy again when using epoxy  Because the fiber of Denim it's self will not let the epoxy penetrate it Denim is a type of woven twill fabric, usually made from cotton.  It consists of two yarns that are woven together. this Processes all so Make it Hard for the epoxy penetrate Into the fibers. the fibers will always be fuzzy. Keep Up with the experimentation.

I have a denim thought, but first,this is amazing. As a sewist, I love hearing all the expected woodworker criticisms (its like that in the sewing world as well), but here's the thing, I don't watch woodworking channels, I watch your because you're always pushing the boundaries and experimenting. Anyway,  Denim is one of the most densely woven twill fabrics around, it's not just warp and weft threads that have been woven, but the interior structure is almost as like a friendship bracelet, tons of threads compressed. Denim is also mercerized, meaning the fibers have been treated to withstand moisture, which is probably why the epoxy isn't soaking it. Im not sure if it could be stripped or not, but most fabrics are treated/starched... unless you buy fabrics meant for dying, those are stripped and ready to receive dyes.
Curious as to why he is bothering with insert bushings when surely the epoxy/denim matrix would be strong enough to support direct tapping and is thick enough to plug tap?

if it's anything like kevlar (which does something similar) when you cut it, the denim is resistant to shear and the epoxy is not so at a microscopic level you're essentially braking the epoxy around the denim fibers which themselves don't perfectly cut through leaving you with the fuzz you're describing.

Always love your videos sir! Long, long time viewer. This one blew me out of the water thought you know it‚Äôll be expensive but maybe I‚Äôll buy this one.. 17k? Adjusted title - I made a Damascus denim art table. Probably still a deal passed on the hours of work, just some sticker shock.
If you wash the denim and remove the sizing you‚Äôll have a better absorption of the epoxy within the fibers.  I know that‚Äôs daunting with the amount of denim you‚Äôre using.  Just use plain soap no softener and I would line hang them, don‚Äôt use a tumble dryer.   I don‚Äôt know how humidity affects epoxy, but I do wonder about the layers delaminating kinda like melamine when exposed and with the sizing contributing to that.  Edit:  It is gorgeous and something you should explore further.   Make a topography map of Mordor or some other D&D map!  There‚Äôs a lot you can do with the technique.  Well done

the breather cloth is to keep an airway open for the vacuum to get through the whole bag, instead of pulling a vacuum in one section and sealing in an air pocket.
Denim ! I'm really liking that table top. It's almost got a tie dyed effect to it that's calling out to my inner hippy. I'm not quite as enamoured with the base though. It looks just a little too spindly to my eye.  I do wonder about the long term life expectancy of a table like this though. Like, will the resin eventually yellow from UV exposure? Or what's the chances of the denim (Or some chemical within it's dye) having a slow reaction with the resin?  In todays world, most people don't think about this sort of thing, because furniture has almost become "Disposable" in many folks minds, but I tend to buy furniture that I'll only need to buy ONCE, so the idea of the furniture becoming unusable before I choose to no longer use it doesn't fit well in my head.
When you are placing your vacuum line fitting, place the fitting base under the uncut vacuum bag and push the bag down tight against the fitting and cut a small cross slit in the center using the hole in the fitting base as a stopping point for your blade. This is how we do it when we lay up aircraft carbons structures at my job, works great and we never have to put tacking tape around our fittings

Cam, i think the reason the denim feels soft is because the epoxy do not enfuse the fisical strands, but in between the strands, so after planning, you can still feel the denim because the epoxy filled the cavitys between the woven material.

Denim.  When I was vacuum infusing, the mold/lay-up table would be gel coated, and we made a seal to the mold (like the example video shown) rather than making a bag around the whole thing.  Also, better placement of pucks and using a flow sheet would make it more consistent. Placing feed pucks in the center and pulling to the edges works well on a big thick laminate.  I've never laminated denim, but kevlar remains fuzzy like that.  You might also do multiple laminations with a fraction of the material at a time.  It will require prep in between, but you'll probably get better saturation.

Re resin application, I've seen glue applicators for timber where you have a reservoir below where the roller sits inside the reservoir. I've not thought it out completely but if you incorporate a clothes mangle system to pull the material through and the glue bucket roller plus a helpful camera man a decent battery drill with a hex drive to power it and you may have a semi automated resin applicator. I think that if your mangle has adjustable tension you might get enough pressure to force your resin into the fibres which is where I think your fuzzy fibres comes from.  Thanks for posting. Always talk all the way through it.
I used to do vacuum injection overmolding of PCBs for oil well drilling equipment.  We did bagging, solid molds, and a combination of the two.  One thing that came in super handy was over sizing the vacuum pump.  I got one of the highest flow pumps off Amazon that I could find.  It was used for A/C work, so it needed to be modded slightly to work with molding.  But, it made large vacuum projects so much easier than these compressed air pumps.

Denim. It is always interesting.  I think I can explain the soft feel after cutting.  With the cloth not having its own rigid structure the resin fills the voids and makes the structure. When you cut it the resin is removed in a violent way while the cloth can move so there are longer pieces of fiber sticking out giving the soft feel.
Denim. No further questions.

Denim.  Give a small piece away for the followers üòâ Very nice job
In case you're wondering why the denim acts like an extremely dense hardwood you made a material known as textolite, textolite is made by layering tightly woven cotton fiber sheets upon one another and then infusing them with a resin while tightly compressing them in this case with the vacuum bag, so you could say you are the largest textolite youtube channel,  P.S. I have a suggestion for another project for you, try making a bench with this stuff

More denim. That being said when we make steel damascus we don't always alternate every layer. Sometimes we want a bold line of bright steel or a bold line of dark steel and so we alternate light, dark, light, etc and then put 2 to 4 pieces of dark in a row and then continue with the alternating pattern. Might be worthwhile taking a 12 inch square of the denim to try an make some small practice patterns. The other idea is doing something like a mosaic damascus and creating a pattern then "tile-ing" out the squares in a specific fashion for a replicating pattern which you could then epoxy all together. J Hopefully that all makes sense in the written form. Loved both of the denim tables you have done so far. Thanks for sharing Cam.

Maybe something to check into for some inspiration is the fact that this is the exact same way micarta scales for knife handles are made. Sometimes they use Denim but it's also a lot of other materials like burlap or just layering multiple pieces of dyed wood or veneer with epoxy...also as a towboater, I applaud your uncensored liberal use of the word "fuck" üòÇüòÇüòÇ keep the snowflakes crying lol ‚úåÔ∏èü§ô
The reason the top is fuzzy is cause its at too coarse of a sanding grit. Micarta will be fuzzy till about 400-600 grit, so a higher sanding grit will help solve the problem and give a nicer finish.
As for what‚Äôs happening with the fuzzy part after planning: being in mechanical engineering has taught me a few things specifically about saturations and different materials. For example in chemistry you can change the maximum amount of sugar that can be dissolved in water by changing the temperature. For some fluids, as temperatures increase, you can add more, and for others it's the opposite, whereas temperature increases you can't add more. But I feel like something like this might be happening, with the epoxy, but with the pressure the denim would be under.   The best bet to really figure out what affects this the most, is to do an experiment where you infuse a 1ft x 1ft, by probably 1.5 to 1 inch thick set of denim. And after you can spread epoxy on the denim as you normally do. Now I'd have one where you just leave the block without any pressure , one with clamping pressure, and another with the vacuum pressure. After this and letting the epoxy set, you can cut the blocks in half (end up with 2 blocks, 6in x 12in to see each layer of denim, however instead of doing this vertically cut it on a 45 to make the layers more visible, and see if there is a difference! If there isn't it could be another factor at play like temperature or humidity  Side note I am no expert on this as you but this is my best advice as to why this might be happening. But in short what I think is the pressure that is affecting the amount of epoxy soaked into the denim. Hope this gives you some ideas!  But there‚Äôs a possibility that resin when hardening doesn‚Äôt actually harden in the fabric but all around each fibre.

wood end tables with denim legs! ‚ù§‚ù§

To avoid the big darker or lighter areas next time you could round off the ply even further so there are no flat bits. Could just use the arbour tech and go free hand instead of the router bit.

I wondered how Damascus steel might have some links to the fabric -  the latter is called Damask as a particular type of fabric for clothing.  So I checked out the possibility on the Internet. Here is what I found. Damask fabric was once very valued in the west as suitable for table clothes and cloth serviettes. The damask fabric is revered in Indi and Arab countries for special formal occasions.   The origin of the name "Damascus Steel" is contentious: the Islamic scholars al-Kindi (full name Abu Ya'qub ibn Ishaq al-Kindi, circa 800 CE ‚Äì 873 CE) and al-Biruni (full name Abu al-Rayhan Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Biruni, circa 973 CE ‚Äì 1048 CE) both wrote about swords and steel made for swords, based on their surface appearance, geographical location of production or forging, or the name of the smith, and each mentions "damascene" or "damascus" swords to some extent.  Drawing from al-Kindi and al-Biruni, there are three potential sources for the term "Damascus" in the context of steel:  Al-Kindi called swords produced and forged in Damascus as Damascene but it is worth noting that these swords were not described as having a pattern in the steel. Al-Biruni mentions a sword-smith called Damasqui who made swords of crucible steel.  The most common explanation is that steel is named after Damascus, the capital city of Syria and one of the largest cities in the ancient Levant. It may either refer to swords made or sold in Damascus directly, or it may just refer to the aspect of the typical patterns, by comparison with Damask fabrics (also named for Damascus), or it may indeed stem from the root word of "damas".

I didn't cruise all the comments, but I think the fuzzy denim feel you got may be because the fiber is finer than wood fibers. I'm guessing that wood effectively burnishes when you get to the fine grits. I also think that since you got very little excess epoxy out in the vacuum process, the denim wasn't 100% saturated, so the fibers were a wee bit freer or unbound. So, maybe it is effectively water resistant, but not totally free of microscopic air pockets. Looks great, though! I've done the same effect with layered clay and made small stoneware bowls. I prefer the wood top builds better than the denim. Just my style preference.

No idea if anyone has suggested this yet, but there is an easier way to do a wet layup to get a more even distribution of epoxy through the cloth. wet it out on a flat surface and use a spreader to press the epoxy into the fabric, and push the excess epoxy of the side into a recovery container to use on the next layer. You can then transfer the wet out cloth to the mold, and it will be ready for the next layer on top. Potentially you could do up multiple layers, maybe up to 5 (note I've not ever made a denim damascus table, so my estimate on layer count may be off from working with fiberglass) and still be able to shape the cloth fairly well. Especially with the vacuum forming compressing down uniformly.  Hope I didn't come off like a jackass trying to share a potentially useful tip.

Denim! As a textile artist with a bonafide degree in textiles I thought I‚Äôd pop on here and explain why the denim feels fuzzy after planing it. Even though it‚Äôs saturated in epoxy the long staple cotton fibers that make up the denim have been twisted into a very strong yarn. On a molecular level the cell walls of cotton are arranged in a helix around the central axis of a very long cylindrical cell. Then each fiber is made up of 20 to 30 layers of cellulose twisted by nature into a perfectly coiled pattern. Then these fibers are combed and twisted together in a factory to make single ply yarn. Then several single ply yarns are twisted together to make the cotton yarn that is then woven into the twill weave we call denim. So imagine a large rope that is made up of many ply that is coiled to nest perfectly and intricately together and those coiled ply nest perfectly together to make many multi ply ropes whose coils nest perfectly together, and so on. When you cut through this rope it‚Äôs going to fray and unravel leaving you with a bunch of kinky springy frizzy coils, much like a shag carpet. This is what denim does on a microscopic level. The blades of a planer are not sharp enough to cut the cotton yarns cleanly plus they are only cutting from one direction. The yarns are not being cut at all instead are being compressed, pushed along, flattened and eventually torn apart with each pass. So you are left with a surface that feels like very short velvet. You may have noticed that the denim felt softer when you run your hand in the same direction as the planer blade was spinning. And this my dear friends is why all your sewing friends yell at you if you use their fabric scissors. Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk üòä

So i have a theory on your denim fuzziness. Btw i am no expert whatsoever, but i think the actual denim fibers dont absorb the resin, yes all the strands get coated in resin but on a microscopic level it doesn't absorb into the fiber, so when you cut it, you are exposing all the non absorbed, essentially preserved fibersd. Possibly even flaking away the resin, again microscoplically.Your sealing the denim, its not being saturated. For example, when you stain wood, it pnly penetrates so far, but its still untouched wood in the center. Or a possibly a better example, lacquer or poly, you coat the wood but its still wood underneath. Maybe? Again, i dont know, thats my guess

Denim. So the infusion went well but you said it didn't go through all the layers the way you wanted. Two tips: 1. Try a different catalyst that would not harden until later on. Give it me time to infuse. 2. Viscosity matters. Find a thinner epoxy or try heating and keeping it warm while infusion. But keep in mind that making it warmer could cause it to cure faster.  Just trail and error until you matter the denim.

Nice work! The blue looks cool. It might be fun to see a khaki and brown denim to emulate wood grain. another thing that might help with different "grain" is making the shaped pieces have variable height to them, like a doorstop.
So I think the reason why the denim gets fuzzy again is that the epoxy doesn't completely just apsorb into the denim, rather a relatively small but consequential amount of it fills in the voids between the fibers that the air that was sucked up by the vacuum was in. So then you get a sort of epoxy saturated denim mesh that's blocked with epoxy, so every time you sand it or plane it, you remove a lot of the epoxy and pull at the denim fibers.

Who knew one punch man is also a craftsman
@BlacktailStudio - I might actually be able to help with some info for your layup.  I have some background doing composites work at in an aerospace research environment.  First of all: Good call not trying the "infusion" process yet.  It's NOT easy.  Definitely get a couple smaller projects working first.  The term you'll want to look up for this is "Vacuum Assisted Resin Transfer Molding" (aka VARTM).  The design of the mold is critical - you HAVE to consider how the resin flows into and out of your vacuum bag.  Secondly: Your table is fuzzy because you're not using enough resin.  A critical metric is the ratio (by weight) of resin to cloth.  You'll be  lucky to get down to 1.10:1 resin:cloth with Vacuum Assisted Wet Layups (VAWL, the process used in the video).  That wants to be weighed/confirmed per sheet, and you'll want to pour 1.25x the resin onto your cloth (each layer independently, like you did) before trying to scrape off the excess.  Honestly, even 1.25:1 is a pretty aggressive ratio for a cloth as thick/rugged as denim.  1.10:1 is about as good as you get with thin S-Glass.  I'm obviously not certain that denim will EVER be non-fuzzy because fully penetrating that cloth isn't easy....but weighing the layers and the resin will/should certainly help.  Lastly: It looks like you got the good peel ply.  Honestly, don't expect much better out of the peel ply.  It has a tough job to do, and it's incredible that it's as good as it is.  I only got consistently better results when my resin:cloth ratios were .  There are a few different styles of peel ply, and playing with each for your use case would probably be worthwhile.
Me trying to craft the perfect comment to correct you on everything on the list (loved the video as always lol)

Just a thought, would it be more effective to use a spray gun in a light spray setting to apply your epoxy to each sheet instead of rolling every individual sheet.
I Think it would look a bit better if the wood pieces were a bit more rounded in profile. It would make the islands much smaller with more layers showing, if that makes sense?
Denim is usually cotton, so it makes sense that it would respond well to tools designed for cellulose. It's really interesting to see that it responds to being planed much the way that it does when cut without finishing the edges in sewing (the second any edge isnt encapsulated with something, it fuzzes up). If you wanna keep experimenting with fabric, try a viscose for an even more processed form of cellulose, or ramie/hemp/linen for bast fiber instead of a fluffy seed case.   Wool would probably create a really, really strong composite... But it'd also dull every tool you have and make your workshop smell like burning hair.

The reason the table gets fuzzy after sanding is because that's just the nature of working with fabric. It's still a fibrous material and as you start sanding down layers, you're going to get edges of the top layer that will be fuzzy. Maybe try running a razor or some sort of scraper over the surface that will cut the fuzzy bits away after doing your final sanding and then start coating it?

Pro tip: peel off the peel ply before breaking your product free. It‚Äôs easier that way.

Just in case you are not a self-absorbed a-hole and is interested in what actual Damascus steel is. Nowadays it‚Äôs called Wootz Damascus. And there is a pretty neat documentary about it here on YouTube.  While looking pretty close to the Pattern Welded Damascus it gets that distinct look in a different way (special metal crystallization process). Basically, you melt a single type of special steel and it cools down with that swirly pattern. The result is fairly homogenous on the inside, just with a distinct swirly pattern.  Pattern Welded Damascus is‚Ä¶ a fake. Or at least a method that was originally used to crate fakes. Something looking close to a Wootz Damascus to sell to some gullible noble for an exorbitant price. Since the original thing (Wootz) was not sold on the open market. Looking roughly the same, but with none of the physical qualities. Basically, you take different types of steels (with visibly different colors) and weld them together in layers. Then distort to make look swirly. The thing you get is not homogenous, prone to delamination of different layers and aside from looking nice if fairly unremarkable. But since the shittiest modern steel is leagues better than the best old one (19th century and earlier) nowadays Pattern Welded Damascus is pretty much ok.  Yeah, it is worse mechanically than having a blade made form a single type of steel, but not by much. And it looks kind of cool.

DENIM!!!! LOOOOVE YOUR CHANNEL!!!!! I'm not a woodworker, I am a super fan and enjoy your videos because they're super cool, you build incredible things and the videos are so well made!!!!. I think the reason why your denim is still fuzzy after doing your best to soak it with epoxy is the finish: the fabric finish. Mostly all textiles available commercially ready to manufacture clothing have gone through several processes: bleaching, dying, washing, shrinking, etc. The very last one is usually a heavy softener that gives the textiles their "hand feel". These coatings are doing exactly that; coating each thread and I would imagine on a very small scale, they do act as a micro membrane against epoxy, that gets broken only when you mechanically sand it and expose the inner structure of the cotton thread that makes up the twill denim fabric. Just a thought. Oh, and about the botched boob job design :) you placed the dark and light denim textiles in opposite directions: which (in my humble opinion) adds to the cool damascus effect.
denim which do you prefer?

Denim - maybe the fuzzy feeling has to do with the denim fibers not actually being cut quite as low as the epoxy, due to them being really resilient? Could be when it goes through the planer, the epoxy cuts cleanly around the denim but the denim itself is more 'ripped' than cut, at a microscopic level. As in the fibers mostly getting taken off at the desired height, but a short bit of stubble at the end just getting bent/squished down rather than fully taken off.

Denim. I think the table looks great. The colors really go well together. My best guess about why it remains fuzzy after being saturated with epoxy is because the epoxy fills in the gaps between the fibers, but denim fibers are still very big and when you sand the epoxy down, it exposes the fibers. I think that you‚Äôd need higher pressure to force the epoxy deeper into the fibers if you wanted to have a smooth feel after sanding. Overall it doesn‚Äôt seem like a huge issue since a top coat of finishing epoxy yields great results.

Denim. This is micarta, it's used in making knife scales and handles. Unfinished it holds good grip even when wet, which is why it's used in knives. Usually the desired effect is that oils from your hands transfer to the knife over time giving it a "patina" look, also highly desired in knives. This is one of the coolest things you've made.

Beautiful!
As far as I know the denim becomes fuzzy after surfacing because of how the blades act on the epoxy-denim composite. The blades don't have anything to shear against (like scissors have a second blade that creates a shear point that smoothly severs material), jointers and planers have a set of blades which scoop out material. This works well for hard relatively homogeneous materials like wood and epoxy, not so well with woven denim and cotton fibres which flex and tear even when impregnated with epoxy.(it's kind of like a roided out weed whacker for woodworkers in that the fibres have the chance to to break at point away from the surface leaving fuzzy hairs). If you want to try something silly take a shaving razor to the fuzz and it should go away. Alternatively the more sensible route is what you have done, coat in more epoxy and then apply the finishing process to that new homogeneous surface.

So, this is very close to Micarta.  I make 1911 grips out of denim and construction paper as well.  You can actually create what looks like real grain with many layers and colors of paper.  The denim grips are my favorite material.  I do my grips under pressure in a wooden form.  BTW awesome look!  I love it! The fuzzy feel is something in a pistol grip that I love, sweat and slick grips kinda suck.  My oldest set, about 8 years old is holding up very well in frequent use.  Cleaners and oils do not seem to be an issue either.  I have made a few of the laminates with automotive pearl, metal flake and tri-color pearl in the epoxy.  In room light, low effect... in sun light amazing. BTW, you cannot break that micarta... even thin strips are so tough! I wet sand mine and go to 3000 grit on the laminated papers.  You can also custom shape a grip with a Dremel and finish out with fine wet papers.

denim love it, nice work
Just because it's been used interchangeably for over 50 years doesn't make pattern welded steel true damascus steel, it just isn't and will never be. You can call it Damascus steel, but to say it's true Damascus steel is just wrong and straight up lying.  My guess to why pattern welded steel started to be called Damascus steel, 1. it sounds better and rolls off the tounge easier. 2. it kinda resembles it at times, but they are nothing alike. Denim, but let's talk about your fuzz...   given the thousands of comments already you've probably already had the definitive cause but I'll offer my view after working in composites for a more than a few years (never with denim). The fuzz your feeling are the tips of fibres that have a higher abrasion&cut resistance than the epoxy, which may also explain the resistance through the planer, with the fibres being 'torn' rather than sliced by the blade. Man-made fibres, as in each individual fibre that make up fabrics, don't absorb resin, the resin cures around the fibres forming what's called the matrix (had to get that word in), locking them in place. Check with your supplier and find out how much polyester or anything other than cotton is in the denim.      Great table, seen most of your vids, keep them coming. Neil, England, Prosthetic Leg maker, bald.

As a textile design tecnician i barely know anything about epoxy lol. But this is because even when imbued with substances (stabilizing resin/dye/water) flat-woven textiles mostly retain their structure. This means that when you plane it, you are scrambling the threads at the edge and ‚Äúfraying‚Äù the fabric. If the textile wasn‚Äôt able to retain its structure it would be like planing straight up epoxy.   This specially also happens because of your heavy weight denim, because it has thick threads that make it hard for the epoxy penetrate the threads and fuse everything together. The resin actually goes into the spaces between. It feels soft because you can still feel the fibre itself.    Good non-stretch denim is 100%cotton. Cotton is essentially cellulose, which is also the reason you can work with it with tools for wood. In this case, the cotton is ‚Äúworking like wood grain‚Äù in the sense that the warp and weave threads are like long pieces of cellulose. If you make horizontal or vertical cuts, you can rip fabric. Same as when you split wood.   This is also one of the reasons why denim specifically retains its weave, the resin doesn‚Äôt completely fuse the fabric into one big hard layer because cotton is really strong on a micro scale, and the force keeping a thread together is very high, probably  stronger than the one keeping the epoxy together. It ‚Äúwants to stay a thread‚Äù, just like wood grain.

No, that's not what Damascus is. That's pattern-welding. Damascus is a specific kind of steel. Exactly why it's called Damascus has been discussed, both commonly accepted answers involves the city of Damascus. Actual Damascus steel had a sort of pattern to it. And it was very good and very desired. So, people realized that, you could fake this pattern and claim it was the real deal when it wasn't, and sell it for more than you'd get for your ordinary other steel. This was pattern-welding. Today, in particular, there literally no reason for pattern-welding, we have access to far better steels. So, the only reason to do so is, "pattern pretty". And if you can call it by a cool name, even better!  As you, yourself, noted. As for not liking me...that you want to use the incorrect term for a historically relevant object? Only shows that you're a sad person who're upset that you got called out. Nothing else.

@Blacktail Studio..Hi Cam, You are absolutely right about the fuzzy texture of the denim even after the resin is cured. It does happen with various fabrics including Kevlar. Mostly, fabrics like denim, canvas and even paper is used for making micartas, so you have just made a huge micarta. The fuzzy texture has two reason, either, the fabric needs to have lower Fiber to Resin ratio or has limited absorbance of resin in its fiber due to synthetic nature. I have shared what i have noticed/learnt so far with my limited experience with resin for various applications. I am open for corrections.

Denim! but to answer the question about why you get denim fuzzies after epoxy, the epoxy is only filling voids and although does pernitrate the denim to a certain amount, the fabric itself is still pretty dense. when you plane off the top, you expose all of that original fabric and the epoxy just sitting around it. the individual threads, now cut, can come free. thats the fuzzies you are getting.

When you were curious about why it gets fuzzy, keep in mind that in the epoxy there's still many fibres which the planar exposes and "pulls" out of the epoxy. That is, in my opinion, the most likely reason why.
Denim.
The reason for the fuzzy-ness is the sharpness of the planer.  I know from working on carbon fiber parts that once the Cutter gets a bit dull, the surface remains a bit fuzzy/matte.

This is what I love about YT.  I had a custom woodworking business for 25 yrs that included, among other things, building a functioning miniature craps table (5‚Äô x 3‚Äô x 2‚Äô) out of solid oak as a coffee table.  I know it‚Äôs the only one in the world since I built it from scratch from a photo I took of a real table in a casino.  I had a casino executive offer me $10K for it (this was in 2002), when I said no he offered with $15K, when I said no again he offered $20K and at that point I said ‚Ä¶. No, there is no price to sell it.  Then he wanted to commission me to make him one but since I didn‚Äôt keep any of the jigs I used to make all the parallel chip rails from solid oak I said no, again.  He was not happy.  The point of this story is I know exactly what it takes to create ‚Äòone-of-kind‚Äô pieces and I really appreciate your continual witty smack downs of some of the most dim witted trolls on the planet who continue to infest YT ‚Ä¶. Bravo.üëΩüëΩ

No Denim - Have really enjoyed the foray-into-the-unknown (especially the first video) but I'm struggling with the context and purpose. Sure denim is a great material for *pants* for obvious reasons, but for me, part of the art of building is appropriate material selection, not trying to force a material to be something that it's not. I guess my viewpoint was expressed succinctly enough by Jeff Goldblum in Jurassic Park - "Your scientists were so preoccupied with whether they could, they didn‚Äôt stop to think if they should"
Denim or not to denim....  why not both :)  We will always love the wood, but as an artist it is important to push yourself and try new mediums.  Innovation and progress come when multiple fields intersect, not from hyper specializing in a single field.  Spiral out, keep going

"Fuzz issue" I used to work in the aerospace industry and worked with fiberglass, carbon fiber, and Kevlar infused with resin. We used the same techniques you did in vacuum sealing. However we used an autoclave with pressure, heat and vacuum. That being said, you did a a good job. i think if you use a harder and stronger resin so the fibers do not pull and break the resin when cutting you may have better results and will come out smooth. Your resin is too weak. Love your video, You inspired me.

For the glue squeeze out in the corners theres a person near me that makes a flat back chisel. The whole chisel is flat so you can pay it on a piece of wood and get into a tight corner. He said he sells them to a woodworking company but I cant find it. If youre interested I can get his info for you.
it gets "fuzzy" after working it for the same reason that woven kevlar (aramid cloth) does. I could try to describe how the fibers are interwoven and released by sanding, but I think you're better off looking up sanding kevlar laminates and you'll get a better explanation along with tips and tricks.  In short, unlike fiberglass, where the fibers are, glass.... its a textile so it behaves different..

Denim I think its fantastic and as a cutler I do feel your pain on every smart arse that wants to comment on pattern welding, historically 'Damascus' is more or less a trade-name of sorts starting in the 18-1900's by the various military industrial complexes of the time producing swords and guns for officers and wealthy folks and if they wanted that wood grain, waterdrop kind of look. That's what it was sold as and no one gave a shit then, no one gives a shit now. Anyway, being a youtuber you deserve some further suffering and I would like to see the matching denim office chair. denim-denim-denim. i see the point with the "um actually" people, but Damascus is multiple things. it's an actual place. the capital of Syria. it's a compound of metals laminated and folded in on themselves then etched to make a pattern. it's also a style. it's not worth too much energy to "um, actually" but it deserves a little more respect than given in this video. people being so flippant about what is and isn't Damascus does seem....a little white-washy. cultural appropriative. it's like calling Indigenous people Indians. this is less of a personal call out and more of a societal thing.   however, people that do "um actually" on stupid stuff are worth calling out all the same. sometimes even cool people can be assholes. i just want to note while we're here that fluffernutters are a New England regional delicacy consisting of peanut butter and marshmallow fluff on bread. been a fan since i was a kid. saw it in the list of "we're not um-actually'ing this anymore" and really i think that's a bit of a silly thing to be on the list. it's a real treat in the summer if you have a grill to toast them on the grill a little. so good! personally tho, back to that table....i like how psychedelic it looks. and the wonky boobs! less out of the fact that they look like wonky boobs, but more that it fits into the aesthetics. the weakest part imo is the base. i don't mind the wood choice, or the desire to keep it simple, i just think it's a little thin. i kinda more enjoyed the wishbone style of the other denim table more. all the same, i can dig it.

It likely gets fuzzy after cutting, because the epoxy is hard and brittle, breaking away... the denim is soft and fibrous, clinging on and being fuzzy. Material Science.

Also if there is denim in a finer thickness to get more of that damascus look that could be cool.  For the soaking and that it gets fluffy: I only have a physics background that may explain some of it: It looks like it was not fully soaked - as in not enough epoxy. You had hardly any excess Epoxy coming out and it either never made it into the last frays of the denim or it cured too quickly. Variables in this should be viscosity, curing speed, temperature and the amount of epoxy.  Another aspect to consider is that a vacuum pump does not result in a perfect spread of epoxy.  Also the pump pressure may be too high. If you think of it like wet denim in a washing machine - there is not just "one wet". If your washing machine runs at 1500 rpm, then the denim is still wet, but not soaked anymore.  => so either the denim did not get properly soaked in the first place or the pump pressure removed too much of the epoxy.  If there is no good info on this out there, you can turn that into content itself.

Addressing the fuzzyness. Denim fibers won't be individually soaked by the epoxy, so when you plane them some of those fibers will raise to the surface and give that fuzzy feeling. Compare this to regular wood after rough sanding.  EDIT words

I once use the router to round small circular pieces like the ones concerned you. What I did was to make a hole in the center of the piece, put a wood dowel on it and use it as an "axle" to link it to another piece of long wood that I could then use as a bar to firmly subject the round piece against the router bit but without having my hands near the danger zone.

Denim/agnostic. Damascus Steel, refers to the ancient historical accident of the Element Vanadium being present in Syrian Iron ore deposits, this made the steel very hard Damascus Steel weapons were  the most sort after in the ancient world, especially the swords. Until the ore deposits with the Vanadium ran out, nobody knew what made the iron ore so good. So they kept on making Swords using regular ore, and they were not as good, but they kept the name, a bit like Apple, or Boeing. I liked the table-top a lot, would make some lovely wall art, the base however let it down, looking rather shoddy.
Well using the term incorrectly does not make it right. Patterned steel and real Damascus are different and should never be used interchangeably. It is one of the reasons people are dumber nowadays than they used to be as they no longer know the true nature of stuff because the terminology has been bastardized. Please refrain from making people dumber...remember, you can help prevent idiocy.
Denim‚Ä¶.anytime a new medium is introduced there is uncertainty, at least for me. Your creativity is well beyond mine but inspiring at the same time. I love the look you achieved. Keep up the great projects. Thank you.

i make vac bags every day at work and one thing you to do is make sure there is a release film and felt between the bag plastic , if you have to much bag film touching its self you will have less vac pressure
Denim
Damascus is a very special combination of iron composition with smithing techniques that originated in Damascus hence the name. There are true Damascus iron ores in India as well.  Today the term "Damascus" is used to describe the patterns and geometries that results from the pattern welding technique where the craftsman uses different materials to create a pattern in the finished product. This is not true Damascus though, only a marketing strategy.
Have people never heard of Buffalo wings? They arent made of buffalo. Just originated in Buffalo. Kinda like damascus....
Alright Voldemort. Nice table!
Denim!  I make my own micarta for knife handles, my theory regarding the fuzziness you feel is that the resin goes into the spaces between the fibers a material is made up of, but not into the fibers. The fuzziness is the reason why micarta knife handles have good grip when bloody or wet.

Denim for sure. These fabric tables are really nice; like building an entire table out of micarta. But also, as a sword nerd I can't let this one little bit go - so like, I get the argument for genericized terms and for the vast majority of those options, you're 100% correct. You look up any of those options and you're not going to just get The Brand In Question, you'll get other examples, too. Genericization was actually a universally good thing for pretty much all of those on the user's end, and corporate defense of IPs tend to bring down everyone else, making the product worse for everyone. However, Damascus being used interchangeably with pattern welding actually does have one major downside, in that they're fundamentally not the same thing and the more people refer to all pattern welding as damascus the more difficult it becomes to research the old blade steel that produced carbon nanotubes in its alloy structure. We don't have a different or more specific term for that; we've just always called that damascus steel. In those 39 other instances, there's absolutely no difference between calling it the genericized term and the original name of the object, especially because they're all purely consumer terms anyway. In Damascus' case, we're talking about completely different metallurgic properties and one just flat out isn't meaningfully relevant when referring to the other. It's definitely unstoppable now, but unlike all those other instances, losing the term was a genuine loss for ease of research on the topic. I guess the path of least resistance is to come up with a new term for the historical stuff, but that doesn't address the previous 100+ years of now-difficult-to-find research on the topic. I can't help but lament that the genericization of Damascus steel - a metallurgic term and not a corporate attempt to defend a brand - caused harm, however small it was.

As a denim epoxy specialist, I would guess that the reason the top layer of the denim gets "fuzzy" is because of the cutting/running it through the plainer. The blades are moving super fast and basically "destroying" the top layers of the denim making it soft again. I would also guess that no matter how much you fuse epoxy into the denim, the epoxy doesn't seep all the day into the middle of every fabric strand so the tiny stands of fiber might actually be slightly dry in the very center.
The purple spray gun doesn't seem very effective.

denim. yes.
I do a lot of fiberglass and epoxy, the fibers get fuzzy on any edge or area where you sand them or cut them. When the fibers are agitated  the epoy bond doesn't hold at the edges where they lost the continuity with the rest of the epoxy laminate. It's gonna happen no matter what you do. As is the life of epoxy projects. Great video man.
Denim is one of those materials that go in and out of fashion.  But as proud workpersons we‚Äôre above such things, and denim is eternal.

I learned about composite laminates in a college course of mine. They consist of a fiberous sheet (your denim) layered and cemented with a binding matrix (your epoxy). These things have some crazy properties and applications and I think you just invented your own. What are you going to call it?

20:18 I'm no expert on anything, but no matter how saturated the denim is, there are still denim fibers in there. The tough fibers are probably sticking out of the surface of where the epoxy has been removed. Try a magnifying glass, macro lens or microscope to look closer, see what you find. I'd love to see that!
i feel like itll always be fuzzy, because you cant replace the space the denim is taking up with expoxy. itll always be soaked, but the denim will still be there, so when cut down youll eventually feel it

Denim! Why the fuz? So, as a knitter this is my theory- denim is made from cotton, and cotton fibers are some of, if not, the shortest fiber that is spun into thread. Because it is so short you have to have more turns per inch to get the fibers to grab onto each other. Those tightly spun threads are then plied into yarns for weaving. My guess is that the plys are looser than the threads and the viscosity of the epoxy isn‚Äôt saturating the threads, just the yarns.  So when cut, you‚Äôre getting dry internal cotton fibers from the threads sticking up.  Again, not an expert, and just my theory.

As a proof of concept, it turned out great!  As a finished product it turned out great!  My one critique would be the layout of the plywood pattern pieces: most of them were long-ish, and you arranged them more or less parallel to each other.  And you put the smaller round bits all clumped together at one end.  I think that a more varied pattern, more random, would create a more pleasing overall look.  Few if any long skinny pieces, more varied shapes.  A mix of large, medium, and small shapes, all interspersed.  That would lend the most 'random' type of patterning.  Or, use only long shapes laid parallel, for a more intentional stripe-y sort of grain.  And/or, going off of that, you could go for a specific pattern- like leopard spots, or zebra stripes, or larger giraffe-like spots, or zig-zags, or a gradient of pattern density from one end to the other.  You could even spell out a name or something!  The possibilities are practically endless!  I was concerned when you went in to those certain center areas with the sander, but admit that it was a good choice; they did look better with the distinct center color, rather than the half-worn, see-through stage.  Maybe another pass through the machine would have taken care of them?  But maybe it would have made others.  It looked good, at any rate.  -My 2¬¢

Pedantry is a deplorable fault, and I am ashamed  when I catch myself at it. I reckon it feels fuzzy because the fibers are soft, and the epoxy is hard. The hard sands away and leaves the soft slightly proud and every attempt to change that can only make it more apparent.

The mechanism that makes fabric absorbent is called "capillary action" essentially the liquid is wicked up in the tiny spaces in-between the individual fibers and is held there by friction and surface tension.  When the resin hardens, it's still only in-between the fibers of the material, the surface feels hard and glossy like resin, but as soon as you sand it, you're allowing the individual ends of the fibers to be free again. It feels soft because the fibers are not totally locked in place, and can still have the general texture that the denim originally had, just with the air replaced.
That is fucking cool!
(Denim) well actually, what you are using is just blue diagonal twill weave cotton fabric. You see... denim comes from Nimes France. So, unless you bought your fabric from approved denim dealers originating from Nimes France then you aren't using denim. Looks like what you've made is pattern welded blue diagonal twill weave cotton fabric. Just a friendly note from the Denim Police.

Denim As you sand the denim you cut threads and since the epoxy cannot fit inside the individual fibers you end up with the "tails" popping up and it is fuzzy. With wood, the threads are much more rigid and also have the organic "fiber" structure that held them together in the first place so they don't pop up.
Next time distressed canvas?

Denim. The interactions with Scott and the little documentary like making of sections are really nice. MORE!!!!!
The reason the denim gets fuzzy again is that the epoxy  penetration hasn't reached the center of the tightly twisted cotton fibers. Basically the fabric is soaked through but the yarn fibers aren't. You would need more vacuum than you can achieve in a home shop to get the yarns fully soaked through, it's similar to trying to drink jello with a straw (possible but hard to do).
It definitely more than them and other weird material projects. A maker that I respect once told me that¬†trying new things isn't about showcasing what you already know,¬†it's about learning what you don't. You can only seek Improvement in your skills if you're pushing your boundaries.

Demin table; I love it!
just wanted to make a slight correction, the "Damascus" you were talking about is actually pattern welded steel, which is a combination of high and low carbon steel stacked into a billet, welded together and then forged out and folded. True Damascus steel is actually crucible steel that naturally has high and low carbon spots in it.  I just watched further in the video, while this is a correction its mostly meant as a better explanation of what the two different kinds of metal are, but yes, essentially it is a one way synonym, Damascus means pattern welded steel, but not the other way around

Denim projects are interesting.  I must be old and boring, because I think I prefer your earlier non-Damascus-look effort.  I've been subscribed to your channel for a long time, and almost universally enjoy your dry sense of humour.  I must say, however, that when you said of people who corrected your usage of "Damascus," 'Nobody likes you...' etc. I thought that was unfair.  Everyone's different, Cam, and some people really like clear communication and for people to be on the same page, and for usage of language to be consistent.  Sometimes, yes, it's frustrating being corrected.  But you don't know what was in that commenter's heart when they said what they said.  Sure, some of them may just be unpleasant "trolls."  But it's possible, (you didn't go into much detail, so we don't really know,) that the person was genuinely trying to help you.  For that person to then be told by you, 'Nobody likes you,' that's rough and uncalled for.  Particularly for sensitive type people.  I know you're just a guy who does woodworking and puts stuff on YouTube, but your channel is big enough now for you to be able to make a living from doing so, and, in my opinion, that gives you the responsibility to be a bit bite-your-tongue with some of your comments.  Some people who correct your usage are nice people.  They just like consistent usage, in the name of clear communication.  I don't think there's anything wrong with that.  You may call this opinion overly PC, or woke, but again, I think that's a bit unfair.  Please appreciate the fact that everyone's different, and some folks will get very upset (and justifiably so, I feel,) when they get petty comebacks to statements they may have been making in an attempt to do the right thing, usage-wise.  Remember, I like you and your channel.  I don't mind you being a bit disrespectful in a dry way sometimes, when it's clearly for humorous purposes.  Mostly it is funny.  I wouldn't even mind being on the receiving end of some of those type of "gentle dig," comments myself, because I can usually tell that a) you have a fair point, and b) it's all in a bit of fun (a "comedy roast," is a known thing.)  But this was inappropriate.  Thought you should know.

I think the epoxy/denim turns fuzzy¬†because¬†when the blade¬†of the¬†planer¬†is going through wood¬†it is actually cutting¬†through the wood but when it's going through epoxy¬†it's essentially micro shattering¬†the epoxy¬†ever so slightly in front of the actual¬†cutting edge¬†causing¬†the fibers in the denim to be ripped¬†rather than cut cleanly.¬†Compared to the epoxy the lignin in the wood is stretchy and won't shatter¬†but¬†the epoxy is much more brittle. I'm not an expert but this would be my guess.

Denim, denim, for sure more denim.  I think the fuzzy is because denim is made of thick cotton strings, so the resin can't fully soak the strands solid. When you sand it, much like how the grain lifts for wood, it lifts up soaked wisps of fuzzy cotton that feel soft because they're so thin and springy ‚Äî kinda like with frizzy hair and water-based gels. The top-coat slicks these strands down much like a pomade would to hair, and makes it smooth again.
"Damascus Denim Table" 3 words I never thought I would see together but here we are and it looks AMAZING!

Denim for sure. I'm no expert, but I think the fuzzy denim is because; even though its "infused" with epoxy, on a microscopic level, the denim is still "surrounded" by epoxy. Imagine a bunch of caramel apples going through a planer, side to side they will still have the caramel holding them, but the top surface will be mostly apples. If you were a giant feeling those apples, you'd never feel the caramel.

20:56 im not a denim or epoxy expert, but im assuming that the epoxy is coating the cotton fibers, and as the epoxy is more brittle than the denim, the epoxy breaks free pulling the loose strands away with it. the reason it might feel soft is because the fibers are free standing fuzz like lint glued to the block. you could try to "shave"' it, like with a very close shave razor, or run some sort of blade like that.

Denom, to discuss your earlier question. The epoxy is absorbed into the weave of the material, but not necessarily into the fibers. If you over machine/sand you end up exposing the fibers and have to do a brush coat of epoxy to seal the material.

20:55 The actual reason it becomes "fuzzy" is because when you cut it, you're creating "micro fractures" in the resin, meaning the resin is snapping off, becoming friable around the cut parts, and since like rebar and concrete, the rebar is what "holds it together", you're left with loose resin which goes away, leaving the fiber there, thus it became fuzzy since there's no more resin (until you add some more over it to cover it back up). We see the exact same thing with the fiberglass boats we build (Lagoon 51, 55, 60, 77, 78 google them if you want) when we cut into the hull, there are always some fibers that become "loose" because the resin around them "eroded away" during the cut.

I am also a denim expert having never done anything with it at all. So definitely listen to my wisdom.  I think it gets fuzzy because the planer/saw/sander, etc cannot cut perfectly clean to the point that the fibers don't slightly separate from each other. They are still full of epoxy, but the fiber isn't "joined" except by the weave and epoxy. The blades also produce a slight bit of heat which might help the separation, but I think that is probably minor. I think if you got several off cuts of your tables and tested cutting it with a box knife or something very sharp that isn't going to pull on the fibers that you might see less of the fuzzing. Of course the blade wouldn't get very far before dulling.  Also, excellent idea with the layer of denim on the bottom. Beautiful.
19:35 " What the FUCK did you make now!?" LMFAO üòÇüòÇüòÇ
OK, I lost it when you commented about the screws. Tell us how you really feel. üòÇ
This is gorgeous.
"Sorry gotta call this shit out @Blacktail Studio" I guarantee you did not just 'come across the vacuum bagging solution on your own...that's pretty much an industry standard, LOL.  EVERYONE does that.  ANYONE who works at a prepreg composite facility, be it fiberglass, carbonfiber, it doesn't matter.  If you are vacuum bagging and doing injection molds...that's how it is done.  Period.  Nothing new.  YOU have NOT 'DISCOVERED' something' making that clear for EVERYONE here.  You are bascially doing 20-30 yr old research of composite aeropsace research/R&D, just FYI.

Denim...  Wow!
Glad Im not the only one hording Denim along with wood lol. I Made a set of surfboard fins out of two colors of denim a while ago and got the same fuzz as you mention. I think the Denim goes fuzzy because when your sanding/cutting it with aggressive tools its not cutting the fibre strands cleanly. I've had the same issue with other fabrics and epoxy. I did find as you sand into the finer grits it will go smooth again. On my surfboard fins they were really smooth once I got to around 400. I did end up giving them a quick clear coat to make sure they were fully sealed as they were going to be submerged in water. Really cool to see the denim micarta on a larger scale.
oh definitely denim.  looks awesome
Denim. Maybe you're an above average woodworker, but you're definitely one of the world's top denimworkers.

It is NOT OK to be an idiot. What the "Expert" guy thought was Damascus, and not pattern welded steel... IS ACTUALLY CALLED WOOTZ. it is created with vanadium crystallization in high purity iron-carbon... and thermal cycling NATURALLY! (if you quench the crucible while making the steel, you are wrong. stop. I know you do it, but you are wrong, and thats why you are a failure)(you only quench the final product... after the natural pattern has been formed through the cycles)  NOW! If you make Wootz... and THEN FOLD/PATTERN WELD! you are a fk'n monster... disgusting!... and probably walk on all 4 limbs, you dirty creature.  Also.... how TF is a carpenter supposed to know the history of steel production???... all the way back to Damascus and their source to create Wootz steel (the source being a mine in Jordan with naturally occurring vanadium along with the raw iron.) and then further back to India? India being the original source of the steel that was duplicated thanks to the mine in Jordan.

THIS IS SO COOL!!!
I know you said that it's "Damascus" but the process is making micarta (which also happens to be a brand name but everyone calls it that) which is typically linen in a resin. Usually it's used for knife scales. Something you didn't know üòÇ Also the "fuzz" you described is the individual fibers of the fabric so they can't be soaked in the epoxy.
All D chair üòÆ
As to your question on why it gets "fuzzy". Cotton is a cellulose fiber; it is a molecular solid. The epoxy cannot infuse into the physical fiber. All it can do is coat it and take up the airspace in the woven material. So when it's sanded, one exposes the fiber... fuzz!
But wait! Why didn‚Äôt you use recycled denim?

Denim - with a more creative base, maybe something more organic. love your videos.
The real reason that it gets fuzzy is because as it is getting cut, it will break the epoxy but not the denim. Leaving tiny little threads of raw denim on there. Fiberglass, carbon fiber, micarta etc all do this to varying degrees. If you had the sharpest planer in the world might fix the problem a bit but still wouldnt fully solve the problem

Sharp edges were nicer, more crisp and in nice contrast with those nice round/smooth sides. I always take a smidge of the sharpness to make it more user friendly and durable(as it's easier to dent a sharp edge than blunt, and the damage is more visible on it), but leave it crisp enough to show off the detail and contrast with the rest.

As someone who was that "acktually" guy in the past I watched your list of 40 terms at .25 speed and I agree with them all
Denim. The reason why it becomes fuzzy again could be the same as why it fades, epoxy just like indigo does not penetrate all the way to the denim core so when sanded it exposes the non saturated cotton.
FUZZY  is just a top layer. Epoxy is hard, while denim is elastic and made of long interconnecting fibres. When sandpaper grit hits it, hard/brittle epoxy has nowhere to go and gets scratched out, while some of the tips fibres coming from below are elastic enough to survive one pass(some ends fluff out), untill next pass destroys/cuts them and sand new layer of epoxy, but uncover new elastic tips of fibres in that layer which survives the "shaking, banging and scratching" epoxy out of them... and thats why you never get long fibres as it gets destroyed with every next pass, but always get a fluffy surface from every new epoxy layer pass.
Denim. You've made me curious if one could replicate figured lumber with it. If the underlying topography were  also made of denim..... if rolled up denim were placed on end (like a limb would grow from a trunk)... if another fabric were included(like a bark inclusion)  anyway, cool table!
Denim. Next time, try rolling up alternating layers instead of using the wood. You can make them closer to the surface and then they can be part of the pattern too.

I think the fuzziness happens because the fibers have a higher tensile strength than the epoxy, so when you machine the composite material it destroys the resin but leaves some fibers intact

I'd speculate that the "fuzziness " from sanding is a result of the hard ceramic particles in the sandpaper causing microscopic fractures in the epoxy matrix that enable the fibers to pop up in an attempt to relieve the compressive stress they were under during the epoxy solidification process.

denim if you tell me the catalog number of that Ikea base ;)
For applying epoxy on denim use Graco airless cordless sprayer with largest nossle and lowest pressure setting. The application will be surprisingly sharp/accurate and you wont have any particle fog(mainly due to its difference from air pressure guns, but on top of that largest nossle with low pressure will make it dispense a lot of it, sharp where you need it and without fog). You will save minimum half of the time. Only if job takes less than 20min and quality finish is not needed, brush and roller wins, as there is less cleanup, just throwing away consumables.
Denim. In regards to the fuzziness - yes, the epoxy soaks in, but it does not replace the fiber. So removing the layers will still expose those fibers. Same happens with wood, but maybe it's noticeable because the denim is soft and fuzzy and wood is absolutely not.

fun fact, many of the words you put on screen about corrections, are experiencing or already have experienced what is known as "genericide", or trademark erosion. Basically if a brand is incredibly popular, it can become too popular, resulting in the name-brand version of a product becoming the most widely used term for that product by consumers, no matter what the brand actually is (e.g, most people don't say "I'll do an internet search for this", just "I'll google it", which google really doesn't like).  In extreme cases this can lead to the loss of trademarks if the company responsible for said trademark fails to adequately prevent this from happening (Nintendo avoided this by managing to replace excessive usage of their name with the term "games console" in order to retain their trademarks).
Denim! I would love a desk like this in my house. I'd put some beefier legs on it and use it for my leather work. Very cool! üí™üèæüí™üèæüí™üèæ

Denim
Maybe sharing expertise is not valued, but trying my luck here. With vacuum bag you need to calculate in enough pleats so that plastic can form closely to all contours and is not trying to stretch and therefore rip. Stretching vacuum bagging material would be great, but sadly for a reason or another those seem to not exist yet. And peeling the peelply at least from carbon is extremely sweaty job, usually pulling with all of my power for 30minutes to hour. You got it easily off, but on parts where you have all sides cured and all sides have overlapping epoxy hardened peelply in big mess, it starts to get really really sweaty, no matter if you do it outside in freezing cold. ps. If you want a real challenge, use Kevlar or twaron. You will break all of your scissors,  half of your festools cutting or sanding that, and especially your moral.

Denim is pretty cool but I‚Äôll be honest and I come for the wood and epoxy videos.
the reason the top gets fuzzy is that the strands of material are soft and don't cut cleanly once the substrate of the resin is ground away.  it's a real pest when making kevlar parts, to the point where most people put a thin layer of fibreglass over the top just to have something they can effectively sand to a finish without fuzz.

In regards to the list at the beginning, it's kind of a funny thought. How a specific brand name becomes the universal name for all similar products. Like band-aid is a brand name but the product is an adhesive bandage. human language is a funny little thing.  Although it's pretty simple. Whatever we use the most becomes the well known and most familiar. It also helps when it's a much shorter thing to say.  Also bonus fact. Supposedly the art of true damascus has been lost to time so you cant even make true damascus anymore anyway. So it doesn't really matter anymore.

Denim - I mentioned on the first one you did that I thought it was one of the most striking and awesome things you've made and... I think you outdid yourself on this one. I really like how this came out, the pattern definitely matches the idea. I like how it is with the base, but I feel like if you had maybe gone with an oil that would've stained the wood or given a bit of a warmer tone to it, it might add a bit of that blue/orange(ish) contrast and make the blue *pop* a bit more - or I'm just overthinking it.  re: the fuzziness after planing - I'd guess it's because adding the forms kinda upset the fiber directions and added a three-dimensionality to it, so when you guys shaved off the layers with the planer, in some cases you were essentially cutting "across the grain", which caused some of the fibers to delaminate & stick out, hence... fuzziness.

Just so you know, new fabrics have a sizing on them. It goes away with washing. This sizing might make it more difficult for the fabric to absorb the resin. (It‚Äôs the same with new dishcloths or towels: they dont absorb until they have been washed). I would suggest you experiment by making a small table with new denim which has been wash and dry before applying the resin. I think the absorption would be different. Once washed, denim (and all fabrics) becomes softer and has a more natural feel, and the colour is less harsh. Just a suggestion. Thank you for your videos! Love them!
Denim. Love it! Next time go for 3 or more denim wash shades.

20:36  My guess can be explained directly, but here's an allegory just because: If you fill a house with bees, no matter how many bees you use,  When you blow it up, you will still find splinters of wood in the rubble.  When you take away the surface layer of epoxy, now the top layer is a mix of epoxy and denim shreds. Since denim shreds can and will fluff, since the epoxy can only dig so deep /into/ the fibers even if it /surrounds/ them, the insides of the fibers lift out of their station, above the epoxy. I can't think of other situations where this effect occurs, but I'm sure it's more common than in just these materials.   2:07 Yeah that's true I was that kind of guy in high school until senior year, sort of. I would very often inform people what they're not sure of or when they made a mistake to the point of being bothersome I just wanted people to know what the truth was, since not knowing or being wrong can cause problems later. All it took was someone telling me that they thought I hated everyone around me for not being as smart (their words not mine). I was shocked. But on the other head of the double-sided coin, another classmate of mine always critiqued others but only to her clique, never to their face. At the school reunion 3 years later, ZERO people even ACKNOWLEDGED that she was there.  Sometimes, it's important to let people know directly that what they're doing is problematic. Others, the best way to shut someone up is to pretend that they already have.
"Denim" I love you. Im tired of these forged in fire idiots coming onto my videos talking to me like they actually have something to add

I have no experience but seems pretty common sense why it gets "fuzzy" - blades whirring at thousands of rpm are knocking/shaking/cutting little chucks of resin off the individual thread ends.  Paint brush that you rinse and let dry - didn't get all the adhesive out and the bristles stick together. You can work it with your hands to get them free again, dislodging chunks of adhesive that had just been adhered to the bristles.

DENIM  I'm a clothing designer: The denim gets "fuzzy" as you put it because of these three reasons: - Almost all denim fabric rolls coming from suppliers are coated with a starch or with a softener to be more appealing to buyers.  - The Denim you used has 1-5% elastane woven in for stretch. When you overheat elastane it becomes very gummy and soft. The epoxy could've overheated the elastane.  - Denim is a woven material with the warp threads showing and when put through the planer the sanding/shaving down will cause fraying which will pill and feel fuzzy.
Who got the list?üòÇ

I‚Äôm an engineer, not an epoxy denim expert ;) so can‚Äôt speak to that specifically, but for similar ‚Äúinfused-fiber‚Äù composites like fiberglass/epoxy, it‚Äôs just the mechanical action of planing/sanding. It rips the fibers free. Very little you can do, other than what you did‚Ä¶ put on another thin layer :)

Hi Cam. I am a PhD in materials science. I would suggest the surface remains fuzzy because when you plane it, the blades tend to more deeply slice the rigid epoxy matrix than the pliable epoxy fibres - this because the epoxy is readily cut without deforming where the blade hits it, but the fibres slightly deflect or compress before being cut. - It might be similar to what happens if you try to use a sharp but not perfectly honed razor to cut some hair off your forearm without pressing it against the skin. The hair would bend slightly before being cut, and then bounce back to a (slightly) greater height than your intended cutting height.  - If you rapidly freeze the entire table by submerging it in liquid nitrogen and then cut it you likely would not have this fuzzynes!! Or maybe if you use a non-textile fibre of similar rigidity to the epoxy.
Carbon fiber damascus table next?
Denim.  Loved watching the "grain" appear with the finish application.
Denim, definitely.
Denim. That‚Äôs a cool table cam. Working towards this being my daily job as well. Almost done with the wood shop on my new house
Denim. I have a somewhat crackers idea for you. What if you used layers of denim, rolled them up into cylinders or "denim logs", twisted them, and then epoxy-ed them to create epoxy denim twisted logs. The chop those logs into discs and made the table top out of those discs. Could possibly even use this to make the legs?
Not sure I like such a square base with such soft wavy lines on top, BUT the patterns came out AMAZING!!!  Fairly random compared to what it initially looked like (espeicaly those really small pieces grouped together... they turned out unexpectedly different.... and psychedelic too lol)  I think it's beautiful, and is a GREAT 'experimental' piece...  and you now know what to expect from different spacings between the pattern underneath... but I think you missed a HUGE OPPORTUNITY by not varying the height of those blocks underneath... you left them all at the same height, and this didn't 'stretch' the the distance between the different layers. And that's why each of the 'shapes'  has the same 5 lines with the same exact spacing surrounding them. And on the long 'straight'  shapes all have those 5 long 'straight' lines too.....  - But if you varied the height throughout the shape (let's just use one of the long 'straight' shapes on either of the ends, just as an example) where ever the height was lower, those 5 lines would bunch together and when the height was higher they would spread apart.  - And this way you would have a bunch of 'white/light' islands that stand out, kinda like they're all being circled and screaming "look at me" ... like you're circling a wanted ad in the classified a bunch of times.... I  guess you could say that there would be more variation... more 'chaos' so to speak....  There's NOTHING WRONG with the way it looks, I'm just trying to give you an idea of what would be different with a height variation..... -  I don't wanna make a REALLY LONG book of a comment, so I'll leave more comments instead... that way there's more of a chance you'll actually see one of them LOL! AMAZING JOB! WOW!
