Denim, looks great
Denim. Fiber Glass Canoe finisher here. Just wanted to say that we use paint rollers with our resin all day everyday and only replace the handles about once a year while the rollers themsleves get replaced about once a month. The trick is to keep a bucket of acetone on hand to store and clean your resin tools between uses. Just make sure the tools aren't made with any materials that will dissolve in the acetone.   PS: I love how clean your bunny suit is. Like our rollers we only replace our suits once or twice a year, they look really interesting after a couple months.  Edit: I know acetone is super expensive but you can reduce the cost quite a bit by distilling your dirty acetone and reusing it.

IKEA also probably can  save half of the production costs by simply making 250,000 of a shelf or table or couch... never underestimate the scales of economy when you go into really big numbers of production... A normal woodshop can never get close to what they need in personnel effort per piece as the IKEA process is meticulously planned to work with machines, repeat simple steps a lot of times and use lower wage workers.  A guy owning their own woodworking shop cannot do that for series of one or 3 pieces and will need a lot more per hour than what IKEA plans with.   DENIM. As far as the ‚Äúsoft‚Äù or ‚Äúfuzzy‚Äù feel‚Ä¶is the denim you purchased a blend? Cotton + another fiber?  I think 100% cotton would absorb the epoxy, but the synthetic fibers may resist complete saturation. So there is still uncharted fabric lurking in your pour. 21:00 when you soak with epoxy, it's not like you're diluting two chemicals or something: the epoxy is going through gaps in fibres but the microscopic fibres are still there. So when it gets planed, that blade is going to cut epoxy differently from how it cuts the fibres... Would be interesting to see in a microscope but I guess the fibres are super strong so the blade can't cut them quite as well and just "pushes them over" kinda thing... They bend back up again above the epoxy and feel fuzzy.

Denim. I'm one of those people who hates people calling pattern-welded metal Damascus. Damascus has an actual definition (it's not a trade name like Kleenex). Erm, Ackchyually "Damascus" refers to: .... Nah, but for real, I like those guys. Not only because English is my second language and is great to learn more nouns an else, but because in any craft there are a lot of synonyms and ways of describe the same tools and techniques, and more often than not, knowing the "correct" (there are many of those) term for something makes easier to find old literature about the topic which is great for learning.  Go on Ackchyually people, we hate you but we need you. Btw, did you know being pedantic refers to those eager to teach and later become synonym of ostentation of academic bs when they become "influencers" of the middle ages? Prolly not exactly like that  but I love to be pedantic about it.

Denim, definitely Denim!!!! I love the way you used the wood to create the layered "Damascus" look, and there are so many different patterns that you could try. One of my favourites is raindrop Damascus. The way it's done with the steel version is to drill random holes of different sizes and depths across the whole peice.... in your case, I'd use a sheet of plywood that you could drill the holes into or use a CNC so you can contour the holes for a more natural look. Something that might look pretty cool would be to start at one side or end with a lot of holes and slowly decrease the number until there aren't any holes at the opposite end/side from where you started. You could also try this diagonally ü§î I'd love to see how this would turn out!! üòäüëçüëçüëçüëçüëç
Denim for sure

Short answer to why the table feels fuzzy after sanding. Because engineering polymer density, surface tension and closeness of twisted cotton fibers. No one ever understands the long answers.

Denim, Hi Scott I love the table and I agree with you the 7/8th round over looks right. The ply forms that you put under the denim give you a large amount of different patterns that could be used, e.g. tear drop shapes radiating out from the center either in a standard spread or in a spiral  pattern. Also you have a huge amount of colors of material to experiment with. Maybe you could make the shapes out of old or left over epoxy to save buying ply, also like the fact that you admit to mistakes and explain your techniques and methods of build. Great video thank you.
Hmmm, my experience is working on sailboats.   I've done a LOT of fiberglass work, wood core, foam core, laminate vacuum process to make rudders and dagger boards, etc.  My daughter saw this and said she'd love me to make her tops for her night stands out of pink and whited denim.    So, I have questions: 1.  The wood base is just wood stock, not vacuum impregnated or sliced and laminated with epoxy . . . so will it expand and contract with the seasons?   Would an attachment between the table and base need some . . . expansion room of some sort because of that?   2.  I would apply some epoxy with a roller to the top of the table after sanding, then put on the peel ply.  That will take care of the blush and sanding.   When cured, peel off the peel ply, then you can add another coat of epoxy to the surface or even gel coat.   (This skips the fairing compound step I'd use on a boat, because its opaque).  It would be interesting to do some experiments.    I think maybe I'll try it . . . the table top would only have to be about 2ft x 1.5ft.

In regards to the, "vacuum bag" setup, you should duplicate the, "Baumgartner Restoration" vacuum table. Using a solid surface on bottom and only taping down a top layer reduces the potential leak points by more than 50%. The only addition for your design would be adding release film to the bottom of the work area. Release film should also be reusable so less waste overall.

On the topic of words used incorrectly   Calibur. Calibur is the ratio of projectile diameter to barrel length  What most people think calibur is is bore diameter AKA the diameter of the barrel  To defend my case I would like to point yall to the USS Iowa which has 50 cals for the main battery cannons  Another 50 cal would be the m107 anti material rifle  Or the 50 cal generic heavy machinegun  All of these weapons are 50 cals. None of them use the same diameter projectile

I think you're giving IKEA too much credit in assuming their furniture is going to last until you move...  I refuse to buy their Furniture for 2 reasons... 1) I find it's an absolute NIGHTMARE to assemble - IF you can get it to go together, it rarely ends up square or level and you frequently need to glue the connectors in because they stripped their threads or reamed out the wood hole when trying to screw them in making disassembly for moving impossible... and 2) I've yet to have one last more than 14 months before the fasteners start pulling out of the wood and the entire piece becomes wobbly and/or just collapses and I've never abused or overloaded them...  I will buy IKEA's kitchenware, cups, clocks, lamps etc. (that tends to be very high quality for the price), but NEVER their Furniture...

Denim and wood? Quite like the underside with plywood islands maybe experiment with that concept
Most likely the reason the table gets fuzzy is because while the weave of denim is loose enough for the epoxy to penetrate the weave, the individual threads are spun so tightly that the epoxy can't get in between every single fiber.
Denim is a very pretty material. I think it could be intresting to have different thicknesses and edge angles on the pieces of wood to vary the density of the pattern.

Hi. i have been following your work for a long time now. As someone who has been working on various fiberglass products for about 20 years, i really enjoy your experimentation practices, because that is what a lot of fiber and epoxy work is. If you didnÀãt already know then usually in fiberglass work, molds are made from epoxy and the product from the mold is polyester-fiber. One could use epoxy for everything but itÀãs too darn expensive. I would like to know.. have you ever been curious how your furniture has been holding up up over the years? ItÀãs more of a polyester resin problem and epoxy is quite more resistant to after curing tension warping, but still iÀãm curious. Keep making interesting work and promote work safety when using chemichals. It really is beautiful and inspiring. Greetings from Estonia :)   PS: sorry for possible grammar mistakes, not native üòÖ  PSS: This denim work is really nice and clean this time compared to your first try. Great work.

Denim!  2:10 On the Wikipedia page about Damascus blades there is (or at least was) an impassioned note that pattern-welded steel isn't true Damascus and I just imagine some furious pedantic nerd editing that in every time. Bear in mind that I'm a pedantic nerd, but I'm also a descriptivist rather than a prescriptivist and I only make a point of explaining the history of the term when it's salient and of interest to the audience.  Either way, I am delighted to know that this Damascus denim table will make some furious pedants pop an artery.

GIF / JIF
Epoxy will only infuse and surround the cotton fibers and displace the air within the mould, if you want to try to get the epoxy to penetrate the fibre mix styrene monomer to dilute the wet soak deninum epoxy and allow soaking for about 1/3 of the open time before applying the vacuum for final forming and this will reduce the fuzzies, never trying denim myself you may have to experiment with respect to desired viscosity to achieve complete cotten fibre capillary infusion by the epoxy for project but when you get it right the definitation between plys (pattern) after sanding will make the effort worth while. Also take more time with sealing the vacuum  bag and all fittings and you will get close to 30" or -14.7 Psi of vacuum this will make project stronger, lighter, and give more defination for the mould. Project is bespoke, need to spend more time with base for me they again for me should be in harmony i.e. Bespoke top + Bespoke base equals extraordinary project which it already is due to the incredible originality but for the future I believe with your creative genius refinements are possible maybe consider making parts of base from denim dimensional lumber you make!! I believe that the reason your tabletop became fuzzy is because cotton is a short-staple fiber-that means there will always be fuzz because the individual minuscule strands of cotton are so short that even being totally saturated with epoxy, there will always be some that come free of the epoxy. Because cotton is a short-stapled fiber. It looks fabulous, by the way.

Denim! Cam to your question why do you have "exposed" denim after cutting or sanding. As a person somehow working professionally with resin composites / aerospace I can tell you that it's pretty standard. In opposition to wood, where epoxy soaks into grain, with glass / carbon (or denim in this case) it rather creates a mesh bonding singular fibers. But as soon as you sand or break this pattern epoxy in this region chips away and whole polygon meshing is gone. In regular production you would use negative moulds and/or gel coat so your product surface doesn't have to touched after lamination - just trim edges and that's it. Your method at adding a topcoat is proper in this case and there's no better solution. P.S. I'm hope you'd pick me for your softball teamüòÇ

It goes fuzzy because denim uses twisted fibres, the epoxy only wets the surface of the fiber. And the epoxy to denim volume ratio is pretty low. Compare that to carbon which is made of pretty much solid fibres

Denim - Love this. Some of your other ideas sound really cool. I think the sanded table still feels fuzzy because of physics. The vacuum isn‚Äôt strong enough to force the viscous epoxy to entirely permeate the smallest spaces between the denim fibers, leaving very small bits of the denim (nothing you can see without magnification when it‚Äôs wet or dry) not saturated with epoxy and therefore dry on the inside. When you sand the table, it exposes and microscopically frays those dry bits leaving a fuzzy texture. That‚Äôs just my theory, but I‚Äôd bet you a pair of jeans that I‚Äôm right.

While I don't personally know why it's fuzzy after a cut, this kinda thing has been done before and is typically called a micarta if I remember right. I'm going to make a total guess here and go with what my brain tells me: The reason that the denim becomes "fuzzy" again is to do with the fibers. The materials is a composite of soft but extremely strong fiber strands. The epoxy however is strong but very brittle. When you surface the table you shave off the epoxy at a consistent rate leaving a hard flat surface. The fibers however have the ability to flex and move during this process. It means that you end up with a hard flat surface of epoxy with minute variations in the way the fibers have been cut while they moved around during the planing. Any fibers that stayed slightly longer than desired would be above the epoxy level. The result of hundreds of thousands of fibers doing this creates a soft textured surface. The same thing happens when sanding very soft wood just not on the same scale.

Stunning !  The fuzz that you felt was the cross section of each cut fibers. During lamination fibers are encapsulated lengthwise, they do not wick in to any extent. When you sanded the bumps down, the "unsaturated" center of the fibers was exposed and that is what you feel as fuzzy. If you want real fuzzy, try making a table out of Kevlar/epoxy üò≤Also the bleeder/breather was so saturated with extra resin, you where in a situation of vacuum lock in the lamination area. One way to over come that is to top the 1st Bleeder with a  film ( like the bag) and another bleeder that now act as a breather only. One more thing for your next one, use a perforated film between peel ply and bleeder, it will make the peeling process a breeze. Each layer of material comes off one by one easy peasy.  Love that you are willing to invest that amount of sweat and $ without knowing the outcome. Gutsy You! I can't wait to see what you imagination is going to serve us next.

Denim! There‚Äôs actually a term for this type of fabric-epoxy composite! It‚Äôs called micarta, and it‚Äôs an awesome material. In a lot of contexts it‚Äôs actually valued for that ‚Äòfuzzy‚Äô texture you noticed. It‚Äôs often used in knife handles, because it gives an additional ‚Äògrip‚Äô to the handle as opposed to other materials.

Hello! Just wanted to say 20:51  it gets fuzzy as the epoxy can‚Äôt penetrate all the way into the middle of the cotton yarns that the denim is made from. This is the same for the indigo that the denim is dyed with, which is why denim fades when it is worn and washed causing the indigo to fall out of the warp yarns. Hope this helps.

I like the denim tables, feels experimental and fun like the burned wood. and i know nothing about epoxy, denim or tables but i do know that it's easier to scrape material off of something moderately tough than something very soft.  I suspect that the sanding and cutting and such is taking epoxy from between the threads, fibres whatever they are, and leaving the fibres behind at a certain short length. Like how you can drag a nail file across your nail (no duh) and it takes material off (ditto), but you drag it across your skin by accident and it doesn't. I wonder if you could get a razor and shave your denim table
At the risk of being universally hated for knowing the difference between pattern-welded steel and true wootz damascus, don't let it keep you from reading up on it. Alfred Pendray rediscovered the centuries-lost art by tinkering at his forge back in the 1980's. It's truly an incredible story. The difference between the two types of steel is so vast that it's really a shame the term "damascus" is used interchangeably. Google "Alfred Pendray, Wootz Hunter" if you're interested.

One possible reason for the fuzziness is that the outer cotton fibres swell from absorbing the epoxy and prevent it from getting to the inner fibres. Some old waterproofs used this effect to work.

An analogy for the denim fuzziness: Imagine sandpaper as a bazillion little, slightly blunt, spaced apart rows of chisels. Try chiseling plastic, it'll create chips. Now try chiselling a long fur rug. The hairs just bend and slip and flow to the sides of the chisel.  The sandpaper cuts the hard and brittle epoxy well, but as long strands form from the sandpaper grit unraveling the denim fibers, the sandpaper just ends up combing the fuzz.

Denim Cam, you really need to try vacuum infusion, even on a test piece. It's absolutely magical and would work extremely well with the low viscosity resins you're using.   Also, I'd suggest building a simple resin catch pot that you can dedicate for this application - I've found the clear lid on the degassing pots can sometimes be a leak path if the silicone seal isn't *just right*, and if resin ever did make it all the way into that pot, you'd have to replace all the expensive fittings as they'd be full of resin. Get some 4 or 6 inch sewer pipe, glue a cap on each end, then drill and thread in a pair of simple hose barb fittings to attach your hoses, that way you can always clear them with a drill.   Great video, as always!

To answer the fuzziness question... I have never worked with denem, but here is my guess. The shear force required to cause material failure for apoxy and denim(cotton) are different. Apoxy stretches as it fails, but cotton does not. Also, cotton is much stronger(in tension) and flexible than apoxy... If you look under a microscope as the planer operated, you would see the abusive material in the pulling the denim/apoxy. The cotton would be able to flex around the abrasive while the apoxy, the much harder material would get chunks ripped off. This would leave microscopic cotton fibers covering the surface.  It might be odd to think about, but plant fibers(wood included) are extraordinary strong in tension (with the grain). Or at least that is my guess. üòÑ

I HAVE TO SAY, YOUR FIRST DENIM TABLE WAS A MASTERPIECE.. EVEN THOUGH THERE WERE MISTAKES AND LOOKED LIKE THE END WAS NEAR, YOU FIGURED IT OUT AND MADE AN INCOMPARABLE PIECE OF CRAFTSMANSHIP.. TO MAKE SECOND? THESE SHOULD BE YOUR MOST EXPENSIVE WORKS.. TOP DOLLAR.
One of the interesting things about a micarta tabletop like this: Is that provided it isn't destroyed by disaster (burned, broken into pieces by industrial equipment, etc.) it will look exactly like that 50 years from now. It have very little if any natural degradation. Also it being fuzzy is normal. The individual fibers are still there just held together by epoxy, so they don't move. Once machined you get a bunch of them exposed, and it gives it a fuzzy, but extremely solid texture.

(Denim)The "fuzz" comes from the fact that the fibers of the denim are separating. They're still filled with epoxy, but because the fibers are separated from each other, and that they're so small, they can still have a bit of give in them. A toothbrush is typically made from plastic, but we still call them "fuzzy" for the exact same reason.  This came out really freaking amazing. I kinda want a desk like this now..........
I suggest next vid doing a Damascus denim mammoth tusk :)

My guess on the fuzziness is that although its saturated, the actual fiber still being present (as opposed to outright replaced) is revealing enough exposed surface area that upon adding the hundreds of thousands of - little - surface areas together, you get one giant fuzzy-seeming surface

Denim.
Denim or no Denim, that is the question.  For me, I'll enjoy either one.   As to the fuzziness, here's an idea I thought of but, of course, I could be 100% WRONG.  So take it with a grain of salt.  Denim is not large fibers of cotton.  It's hundreds of super tiny fibers spun into thread (look at it under a magnifying glass, if you're interested - pretty sure they're smaller than the width of hair by quite a bit) and thousands of those are made into your denim fabric.  So when you're sanding it, I think you're 'revealing' the tiny fibers.  And since they're so tiny, they're soft, even with epoxy on them.  Oops!  Forgot to say that the table is a great looking piece of work.

the fuzzy feeling comes mostly from the fact that the denim doesn't exactly soak in the epoxy all that much. you're more so coating the denim fibers in epoxy.

I've made denim micarta for knife handles and one of the great things about it for that purpose it the persistent fuzz. Makes for great feel in the hand.
A couple of ideas regarding the soft touch of the denim after sanding. Obviously it's the ends of the individual fibers being exposed. Which to me sounds like the epoxy is not 100% saturating or soaking in down to the individual fibers. Denim us usually made of twisted cotton. However if nylon or polyester or some other artificial fiber is added perhaps it is resistant to absorbing the resin. Also, most fabrics are treated with pesticides and/or stabilizers which could cause individual fibers to resist the resin. Most sewers (people who sew) wash fabrics to remove these additives before using.  Another thought, are the resin molecules too big  or thick to penitrate the cotton fiber? Does it need more absorption time?
Why you are not constantly calling it "denimascus" is beyond me.
no denim... I just enjoy the wood tables so much, and denim makes me think of high-waisted mom jeans... but I'm never going to make either and this isn't a how to channel anyway, it's an entertainment channel, so if you screw up a couple more denim tables, I'm game. As for the fraying... (and I'm totally guessing here so I could be blowing smoke) the fraying could be a mix of the material (cotton) but also being a fine thread... like if you were to cut a steel rod (no fray) versus cutting a similar thickness of steel but comprised of fine gauge wire instead, I'd imagine it would fray more than the steel rod. Thanks for the entertainment. Carry on with the mom jeans if you must.

At 4:08 I would try using double stick tape to put a smaller diameter block on top of the small piece and then some more double sided tape to stick a large handle/block to that piece. to be fair, if someone who knows the difference between 'pattern welding' and Wootz, calls pattern welding "true damascus"... you're inviting criticism by being 'wrong'. (People have been calling pattern welding 'damascus' for over 50 years, because the secret of wootz steel (vanadium), and its production, wasn't rediscovered until the mid 2000s (at least, admitted publicly, as the main guy to reveal it had been working on it for decades), with workshops just in the last 10 years being set up to show people how to produce.... true damascus)

Cam, the denim fuzziness is just a function of denim micarta. A number of fabric micartas do this, it's the threads of the original fabric

MOAR DENIM!  - I bet Walter Sorrells would love to get one of these...  EDIT: @1:44 The 'damascus' vs. 'pattern-welded' debate ended decades ago. ALL real smiths use these terms interchangeably. The language simply has evolved, and the only people who'll still start arguments about these terms are guys who, at absolute best, have forged a handful of blades, but usually just dweebs who watched a few YT videos, or maybe read a book on the matter.

The "true damascus" bit was funny, but it got me curious to know what "true" damascus really is. And I found out that the original damascus steel wasn't layered like the modern version but naturally emerged from melted steel solidified with some specific forging process. I didn't know that was possible, but it sounds really neat!

I've done a few "matte" or satin finishes with epoxy.  Its easier than finish  sanding to buff.  Sand throughly up to atleast 1000 grit.  Then a simple car wax.  My next one I'll finish with a ceramic coating to see how that works over the 1000g or 1500g.  But it looks great.  It feels live velvet. And you cant see any swirls or pigtails from the sander.

About the fuzziness.... at the end of the day, it's still a fabric and even though it's been infused with epoxy, it will still behave like a material when sanded because the sanding is tearing at the material where a saw blade just cuts it cleanly.  finishing it should be basically the same as finishing a wood surface- reseal the material and sand it smooth. Possibly two coats but you already know this.

Denim. Why does the denim get fuzzy? Reasonably sure it's because when you sand the epoxy off the fibers will make their way to the surface, and the sanded fiber at the surface will fray leading to the fuzzy feel. By adding that last layer of epoxy back on, you're trapping all the fibers again and making it feel like epoxy again.
2:06 LOOOOOL
Cool! I think it would be cooler with a more natural pattern though :) If the initial shape of it would be like a naturally folded cloth. For example you drop a cloth on a flat surface, let it have some folds, maybe move around a bit to make more folds. Then when you like the shape, you can spray it with something that would harden it, then pour plaster to make a hard durable mold, and there you have it - a natural cloth looking mold.

I'm not birching but true Damascus is not only the folded over metals over and over but it also creates a very hard metal that can keep an edge like no other.  I got duped on Scamazon years ago and didn't read the fine fine print and ended up getting that laser engraved Damascus print and it cut like a stick of butter threw a brick.  I got a sweet sharp edge on it and the air dulled it transporting it to the cutting table.   My true Damascus cut the edge of my thumb nail off and nicked the corner of my thumb and didn't feel it until the potato I was cutting turned pink lol
